This is the best Farm Sim out of any so far. However to start this off there are no major bugs. 
Thus be prepared, this Farm Sim has a pretty steep learning curve. Equivalent of just driving into a wall. It's a ton to learn and take in, just in the basics of equipment operations and field preparation, that doesn't include the added difficulty that comes from, animal husbandry (6 different animal types), crop management, crop yield boosts, and production chains. 
Don't get me wrong in anyway the game is great, but controls are incredibly unintuitive, physics are um something, the game does a HORRIBLE! job of explaining literally everything, and finally if you want to download mods via the in game mod launcher good luck your gonna be sitting there a good few hours. 
Besides that I'd highly recommend this game and if the dlc (espically the seasons passes) are on sale get em.

Farming Simulator 22 is an immersive agricultural experience. For players who’re willing to spend hours trying to make the most of their farm, it offers a lot. You can choose to focus on your crops, animal husbandry, or forestry. Fans of the series will be grateful for the official implementation of seasons, and the production chains mean there’re even more ways to make money and grow your empire. It doesn’t cater for new players in the same way, but there’s still a hook for amateurs to get going. With some lovely visuals and a faithful simulation of real-life farming, you’re not going to find a better game out there.
Its perfect game for people who love farm life.

*UPDATE: It's now (February 2024) 2.5 years since FS22 released, and nothing's changed. The game remains buggy, unfinished, and performance is still terrible. It's arguable whether this game is ready for release in its current state, but I definitely cannot say it's worth paying full price for this. Despite how many hours I've spent on the game, it still very much feels like a beta at the best of times, and it's only thanks to mods that it's all playable for any extended amount of time. There are now a couple hundred major and critical bugs and issues that Giants still refuse to fix or even acknowledge, and for a company that's done nothing but release the same game over and over for 15 years, it's mindblowingly mystifying that they flat out refuse to work on that very same game. Instead of working on their only product, Giants instead focuses on procuring licenses for as many brands as possible, with zero consideration for how relevant those products are to the game, thus we have a dozen (buggy) DLC where the majority are effectively repaints of existing stuff and thus a complete waste of money. Below is my original review, which I still stand by, as nothing's changed since I wrote it 2 years ago.

For FS22, Giants spent a year in lockdown ripping off mods. Nearly every single new feature in the game are all stolen from mods for FS17 and 19 - that's a good 20 or so mods they've copied and pasted into the game. They've done it so liberally that the parts of Seasons and AutoDrive they've stolen even display the exact same buggy behaviour as the mods for FS19. Giants's own contribution? Field stones and rollers, neither of which add anything relevant to the game - in fact it detract since you'd be hard pressed to find a farmer who uses a roller, let alone the way the game wants us to. This literally means that Giants want $44 for the same game as FS19, with a bunch of mods added they weren't involved in the development of, meaning they're charging for someone else's work. Is the game playable? Sure. Should you buy it? Well, if you don't have FS19 and it's on sale, perhaps, but if you do have FS19 then you just have to install a few mods to get virtually the same experience (and 19 is more stable too).

Meanwhile absolutely nothing has been done to fix any of the problems with the game. Overall performance is still terrible, thanks to the game still running everything off a single CPU core - the promised multithreaded performance improvement is nowhere to be seen - which means the framerate still tanks massively at random for no explicable reason. The game is also still unstable and it is very easy to get it to lock up just by having more than 3-4 helpers going at the same time. And because the game only runs on a single core, throwing higher performance hardware at it makes zero difference, the game simply can't utilize it.

Speaking of helpers, they're if anything worse than ever. Just as useless as they've been in the past 12 years, but now they're even more glitchy and will happily stop in the middle of a field for "unknown error". They still won't stay on the field, they still turn around in crops and need a whole field to turn around because they don't know how to make 3-point turns, they bitch about stuff "in the way" way outside the field where they shouldn't be going anyway, they won't follow the edge of the fields, and the list goes on and on.

Giants still tries to shove as many brands into the game as possible and don't care that there isn't a proper spread in the equipment selection as a result, or that some of the required equipment is missing. So we have issues like the US corn planters that don't have fertilizer tanks because you're supposed to have fertilizer tanks on the tractor, which don't exist in the game, which in turn means you cannot use this equipment the same way you would IRL. This of course comes from the fact none of the developers know anything about farming and are too busy making DLC to learn. 

And then we have the ongoing issue where Giants refuses to fix bugs, glitches, and everything they do wrong. Like when they added the Xerion 5000, but the tracked version goes 50 km/h even though it is limited to 30 km/h IRL to not destroy the tracks, and the wheeled version is missing all the wheel options Claas offer, even though they included those very same wheel options (correctly) with the SaddleTrac and the Class DLC for FS19. Even though it only takes a very simple change to the XML to fix it (so a couple minutes copy pasting at most), Giants insist they won't do it. Just like they won't fix the sugarcane planter where the wheels don't turn so it's impossible to reverse with it, the bale grabber that's hardcoded to the wrong keybindings, and many other minor things that could be easily fixed if they just bothered spending 5 minutes editing the XML. It is absolutely petty that they won't spend a few minutes fixing minor things, almost like they want to look like a bunch of raging amateurs, and their attitude to bug reports more than underline that they don't care about the quality (or lack thereof) of the only product they make.

I don't have much with farming but watching other people play I saw that it had some depth to it so I decided to make this my time filler while I take a break from my usuals. After a rough start trying to find my way through the slightly ambiguous UI (it took me way longer to figure out how to sell chickens than is necessary...) and having trouble figuring out what all the machines are for, I started to get the hang of it. The tutorial is dreadful by the way, I learned to play by doing two false starts where I just threw away money buying random machines and learning how to use them before I started the third serious playthrough.

And after 50 hours of play, I... kind of go back on my claim that it has depth. It has some depth, but not as much as I thought it had. To me it feels like an incomplete sim, a beta version for the full release which might just be Farm Sim 24/25. Part of the game feels rather complete. You can plant grains and other goods, harvest them and they form feed for animals, materials for other products in a product chain or you can just sell them on their own. That's fine. Except its extreme busy work because to properly prepare a field you need to plow/cultivate it, fertilize it twice, roll it, optionally remove large stones, lime it and remove weeds. Good god. I would really recommend turning off stones, that is just one grind too many. Thankfully the game is very configurable.

You can let tasks be done by the computer so you can multitask, or you can do multiplayer. A common thing to do is that one does harvesting and the other drives a truck next to it to collect the product so the harvester never has to stop to be emptied. It's just... the AI is dumber than a doorstop. One tree and they will ram themselves right into it and get stuck. They get stuck on corners so you can't trust them to even drive your equipment from A to B successfully. Under-developed to say the least.

But I wanted to do a chicken farm. And... chickens are in my eyes really under-developed too. You buy them (pretty cheap, to be honest), they magically transport themselves to your coop and if you just keep the food storage from going empty, they will on their own grow, multiply and produce eggs which you can sell or put into a production chain. And that's it. That's chickens. If the coop didn't radiate some clucking sounds I would confuse them for being plants. It is almost passive especially if you compare it to growing crops. Oh yeah you have the option of putting roosters in your coop so the chickens multiply faster, but truth be told... you don't need them. Chickens multiple like Gremlins in a swimming pool already. 

There is more you can do. You can do forestry which is kind of a cheat way to get money quick, but the game needs that because otherwise you'd be left with only the option of cheating your way into money with mods, or taking out huge loans and have them be a pain in the neck. In the official maps the devs hid collectables all around which are worth a thousand bucks a pop so if you manage to find them (and they are not well-hidden) that's a few free cheap machines right there. You have greenhouses which are largely passive if you provide them with water. If you install mods you can do things like solar panels to make passive money. On the planting side of things you can plant cotton and setup fields of olives and grapes which have their own unique way of prep and harvesting. You can plant root vegetables like potatoes and beets, but they are a massive pain in the neck to harvest. It takes for-e-ver and you need specialized harvesters to do so which are very slow. You can also do grass which is food for animals, or turn it into hay or silage. A lengthy multi-step process requiring several machines and transports.

Long story short. Lots to do... it is kind of fascinating because of the many different machines you get to drive around and use but a pretty shallow experience nonetheless. I am a little disappointed. I have more fun watching other people play it while they edit their videos to skip over the waiting parts than I have playing it myself where there is no skipping.

This game is really cool and relaxing! The graphics are better than I expected and there's some nice physics when you drive over crops and grass, so the world feels more real because of that. The only thing I'm struggling with is the learning curve. It's not like ETS2/ATS where you can pick it up and drive without any knowledge of trucks; you kind of have to have some knowledge of how the machines work, or just look it up on Google. It reminds me a bit of Warframe where you have the wiki open every few minutes. I didn't know how to empty my combine harvester until I looked up a video about it - now I'll always know how to do it but it's just a bit of a challenge to get started. I'm sure once I've figured everything out it'll be great but please just keep this in mind!

The Good:
This simulator version is beautiful, on the surface that is, and the inclusion of production chains into the main game is a good idea but not without an entire new set of bugs. There's a new crop 'sorghum' and the draw distance has improved 'somewhat' plus a list of other new features including new vehicles/equipment that are super-detailed, even the electrics cables are modelled with the air lines and this is for every trailer and implement. The sky looks good and better than before but needs work, the storms are nice, and there's seasons with snow.

The Bad:
BUGS! There are bugs that should NOT have been in this software at release and I expected a lot more from this developer after so many game versions. I also think that the Giants team may be 'drifting' from their roots and the outcome of these new ideas is showing through like a turd in a swimming pool. UPDATE 2024: the bugs are still present, after all this time WTH?

The Ugly:
This version of Giants farming simulator introduced advertisements EVERYWHERE, and they are DLC adverts, even when the server is serving you adds, and when its all up and working properly, you will get 60 of them, that's right folks, 60 Billboards & Signs! In your face everywhere! Offline, there is 'mass' FrizzySpizz soft-drink spamming! (these soft drink signs may be replaced with even more DLC 'flogging' but I have not checked lately as this game is no longer enjoyable to me and I rarely play it anymore)

The Verdict:
After many hours of game play, I can say without any reservation; don't buy it unless on sale and even then, be aware that the DLC is simply not worth it (the platinum expansion was OK but not worth the writing home about). And the 'popular' passenger script is hidden behind a DLC paywall instead of being included in an update like it SHOULD'VE BEEN! That's just a pathetic money grab. The basic game price is OK but all the DLC is over priced for what your get (most of it is in MOD form anyway). 

Also, the boxed set is seriously 'lacking' for a better word.

---------------------

Final word -- 60 advertisement objects in the US Map and 40 in the others, really Giants? come on...

The 'very positive' review count is based on a massive fan community from Europe and can not be trusted as a sign of quality because all the FS releases get the same review status. 

I doubt very much if I will purchase your next FS Giants as I believe you have lost your way and are simply NOT listening to your community at all!

I am AgamemnonGames, my journey with Farming Simulator had started with FS19 on the PS4 and later on had moved over to the PC. Recently, I had purchased FS22 through Steam. It has been a wonderful experience. The way I play the same is with Season and a 28 Day monthly cycle. I am still on Year 1 of my farm using the Fox Farm map. 

The big change for FS22 from FS19 is the level of detail we have to pay attention to with Cultivation with plants and with the nurture of animals. I like that we have to add those things to the game. So the people that do not want to play to those advance details of farm life can keep is simple. For the advance player, we can add more depth to the game.

What do I like most about FS22?

I like the little things we have to learn with animals and plants. There is a huge list of line items to learn.

For example, Horse Care, I prefer to ride the horses and train them rather than put them in a production cycle and press a button. The game allows me to enjoy the aspect but the game does not force another player to do what I do. I wish that we could treat the hooves, and medical care of the animals and plants. Also, I wish that we could include the grooming care of the animal too.

I like the Pump and Hose DLC. 

This DLC has been a challenge for me. There are many parts to this system and you need to be aware of them all. However, the DLC has been very fun for me. I like learning new things every time I play the game.

What do I dislike about the game?

For me, the problem that ultimately arises with Farming Simulator is that you put so much time and labor into the farm then you have to throw it away every two years to keep up with the production cycles or the game developers. That is hard for me to do. It can be painful.

I do recommend the game to other people.

God Bless and Thank you

As a complete newcomer to farming games, start a new game and try to fertilize your first field after harvest (or change crops).  There are many problems that you will encounter, the first of which is that [b]basic info is not available in game[/b].  There is a brief tutorial that covers <5% of the game play and a wiki style overview of high level topics.  There are no tool tips giving additional information on tools/machines or additional requirements for a particular job.  Players must seek online help in order to fill in the knowledge gap and develop skills needed for the higher level wiki topics to become relevant.

A wise man once said, to forget how to dig the soil, tend the earth, is to forget ourselves. Well maybe some have. But a few of us still know. You gotta be willing to put in the time. Make the sacrifices. And the hard choices. The job's got its perks, don't get me wrong. The sweet smell of the morning dew, the way the warm sun and the cool breeze can dance across your skin. But don't think it's a game. The farm's got a way of sorting the wheat from the chaff. Just remember to keep your wits about ya. You fall...you get back up again. Because this is more than just a job. It's a calling. Who else would choose to wake up early in the morning, tear up their hands working in the field all day, and then spend the evening planning how they're gonna do it all over again...better...tomorrow? Day after day. Season after season. Year after year. That's a calling that's never ending. It stretches far forward and back from us as long as farmers have been tending this earth. And farmers will be around as long as such a thing exists. Tomorrow will be secured by those willing to dirty their hands today. So when you feel alone out there in the field, just remember, you're not. Think about all those that have come before you...and all those that will follow. Plant today, harvest tomorrow.

I am a farmer myself and can share with you that the economic difficulty in this game is not the same as in real life. 
But the game gives people a little perspective of some of the work actually needed in order to be a farmer. It still misses a lot of things, but is understandable why it's not included in the game. 
Compared with the previous Farming Simulator games throughout the years, FS22 has improved graphics and physics. 
A lot of work in physics is still needed when it comes to pallets / logs or anything else that has to do with front loaders and cranes. 
I also miss a lot of tractors, but thankfully it is a lot easier now with the downloadable content menu inside the game. In previous versions, you had to download these manually from the internet, where they often didn't work as intended. 
Other than that, it is a great game with a good concept!

Thought I'd give this game a go, since I love farms (specifically husbandry) and thought it would be nice to build up a little farm on this. When I first got it, I struggled but decided to keep pushing through and trying to make it work. I wanted to give it a chance, because at the time I wasn't aware that I only had a certain amount of playtime before I could refund it. I went for a refund and explained the situation, was denied. So admittedly I am salty about it and regret trying to give it a chance (I gave it a chance because I thought it was just me being a bit dumb and that things would get easier). Since I was stuck with it, I decided to keep playing. I have 24 hours total on record and while I have learnt more than I did initially this game is still quite stressful and I still see it as a waste. 

This game is made for a particular type of gamer and if you're a new player looking to try it out, please look into the refund time limit before hand and refund it if you find it a struggle within that time. Don't make the mistake I did, you can always try it out again later or wait to see if the game is discounted.

The gameplay is very faffy and tedious, it becomes frustrating very quickly. There's only so many times one can drop a bale of hay before they ragequit. I don't believe even saints have the patience for those damn bales LOL. 

The game also has a lot of bugs. I've noticed things are very easily sent flying, two vehicles giving each other a gentle smooch sends them twirling into the air like some deranged ballerina. Admittedly, this was the best experience I have had with this game. I love the quirky bugs, they provide a breathe of fresh air. A break from the damn bales!

Mods make the game way more tolerable. They have been my saving grace for a lot of things, but it is still frustrating. The mod support is pretty good from what I've seen.

A major part of the gameplay involves growing and transporting produce. I have only dabbled with the plant side of farming a couple of times (preferring instead to cheat cash to design my farm how I want it or to try out different vehicles or mess around with the animal side of things), so I can't give much on that aspect. However, transporting produce is a nightmare. Trailers and trucks are awful at turns (unless you want to make multiple small trips with a small trailer across the map), the NPCs have clearly never even seen a driver's license and reversing with a trailer is a nightmare. My tractors wear them on their side like a rich lady wears a designer handbag, I swear. 

Farming Simulator players are a different breed of gamer and they scare me tbh (anyone who can faff around with stupid bales and handbag trailers for "fun" is not human, I don't know what they are. I don't think I want to know LOL). However, I respect that they enjoy this game and clearly the game must be doing well to have so many versions of it. Like the FIFA of farming. It just isn't the game for me and people like me. As I said before, feel free to give it a go just make sure you know your refund time if it doesn't work out. 

I will now dip and avoid playing the game for many months, before deciding to reinstall it, rage at bales and quit for many more months.

Farming Simulator est un jeu qui, malheureusement, pâtit de plusieurs aspects décevants, notamment en ce qui concerne les collisions des objets. Les poteaux électriques et les voitures non jouables semblent toujours être placés de manière à gêner le joueur au pire moment possible, rendant les déplacements frustrants et parfois même agaçants.

Un autre point négatif majeur réside dans le manque d'informations sur des éléments apparemment simples mais cruciaux. La recherche constante pour résoudre des problèmes mineurs devient rapidement ridicule, ajoutant une couche d'irritation inutile à l'expérience de jeu.

Le temps d'attente entre les différentes tâches et le manque de diversité dans les activités disponibles une fois que toutes les tâches liées à la croissance des plantes sont accomplies contribuent à un vide de gameplay. Cette lacune laisse le joueur avec peu d'options, ce qui peut s'avérer ennuyeux et peu stimulant. (Utiliser le lits pour dormir 5 fois pour passer 5 mois)….

Un aspect particulièrement décevant de Farming Simulator est son économie peu inspirante. L'obligation d'attendre le moment parfait de l'année pour vendre ses produits peut sembler réaliste, mais dans le contexte du jeu, cela crée une frustration inutile. L'idée de synchroniser les ventes avec une période spécifique pourrait être un choix intéressant, mais elle est mal exécutée ici, entraînant des périodes d'inactivité déconcertantes.

Cependant, le jeu n'est pas dépourvu de points positifs. Les animations des divers outils agricoles sont indéniablement bien réalisées, offrant une esthétique agréable qui contribue à l'immersion. Malheureusement, ces aspects positifs ne parviennent pas à compenser pleinement les lacunes majeures du jeu.

En résumé, Farming Simulator souffre de collisions agaçantes, d'une information insuffisante sur des éléments simples, d'attentes prolongées et d'une économie déconcertante. Malgré des animations visuellement attrayantes, ces points négatifs plombent l'expérience globale du joueur et laissent une impression mitigée, voire décevante, du jeu.

Fun for a bit but gets boring. First off, if you do not have a good PC, do not even bother. It lags even on high-end systems if you have any mods installed at all. Most cool mods are locked behind a paywall; most you can find leaked, but some are too obscure to find. Lots of the Patreons are just little kids who are ripping off someone else's mod and making it drop your frames by 20 while having like 2 features.

I have never really gotten into farming because I have no motivation; I just prefer to build cool farms then move on. Most of the tractors in the game have pretty nice customization for a tractor. I just wish that there were more incentives to be able to own a small-scale farm with smaller equipment. The forklifts, pallets, front loaders/wheel loaders are a mess, also when you are playing on a keyboard without joysticks, same with the forestry machines.

The DLC packs are overpriced for what you get and are not worth it. (I can hook you up though; comment on this post). The snow plowing does not work correctly even with base game implements. Sometimes you are plowing, and you will just leave a bunch behind. Animals are not worth it in my opinion; all you need to do is give them food and water.

The game, like I mentioned earlier, is terribly optimized, and if I remember correctly, it runs on a single core? Don't quote me on that, but either way, it does not run very great on modded maps. The whole point of the game is to build a bigger farm, right? But in the beginning, the game is really slow, and there is nothing to do when waiting for crops to grow besides just skipping time, and that feels cheaty.

If I had people to play with, I bet I could get into farming, but I just can't recommend you to buy this unless you like repetitive, boring gameplay or have friends to play on a server with. If you want some mods, I can also hook you up with those; I recently trimmed my mods to mods that are actually good and don't lag your game. I wish I could give it a positive review, but I feel like the devs don't care about people who can't afford to spend 8 bucks for 2 new tractors or the entire cost of the game to get one map and a half-assed forestry system. The majority of people cannot afford joysticks, but then again, with a mouse and keyboard, you are limited, so I'm not sure how to fix it. If I had the choice, I would give it a mixed rating, but because of what I have said, I'm not going to recommend it. Thanks for reading! ~Conor

Having spent an immersive 22 hours delving into the lush, vibrant world of Farming Simulator 22, I am thrilled to share my experience with this remarkable game. This latest installment in the Farming Simulator series is not just a game; it's a virtual gateway to the serene and rewarding life of agriculture.

The game offers a vast expanse of farmland, presenting an array of activities that are both engaging and realistically portrayed. The attention to detail in the machinery and farming techniques is astounding, providing an authentic farming experience. Whether it's the roar of the tractor or the gentle sway of crops in the breeze, every aspect of the farm life is meticulously crafted.

The addition of new features, such as the dynamic seasonal cycle, adds a layer of strategy and realism. Managing your farm through the changing seasons, with their unique challenges and opportunities, is incredibly fulfilling. It's not just about planting and harvesting; it's about being attuned to the rhythms of nature.

The game's graphics are breathtaking, with picturesque landscapes that make every moment in-game a pleasure to behold. From the golden hues of a sunset over a field of ripening wheat to the crisp, snowy wonderland in winter, the visuals are a constant delight.

Multiplayer mode brings a communal aspect to the game, allowing you to collaborate with friends or other players online. This adds a social element to farming, where you can share strategies, help each other, and enjoy the fruits of your labor together.

One of the most impressive aspects of Farming Simulator 22 is its accessibility to both novices and seasoned players. The game offers a range of difficulty options and tutorials that make it easy for anyone to jump in and start their farming adventure.

In summary, Farming Simulator 22 is a beautifully crafted game that offers a tranquil yet engaging escape into the world of farming. Its combination of realistic gameplay, stunning graphics, and a multiplayer option makes it a must-play for anyone interested in experiencing the joys and challenges of agricultural life. Whether you're a farming enthusiast or a casual gamer looking for a relaxing experience, Farming Simulator 22 will not disappoint.

I have loved this game for years. I first received the game for Christmas a few years back when I got a Nintendo switch. Playing that was all I could of ever asked for. However, as soon as I upgraded to a PC about a year ago I stumbled across YouTube channels featuring mods(Huge shout out for The Squad & Austin Farmer). This made me go on some sort of mod spree where I downloaded cool maps, trucks, cars, tractor, even boats, you name it. I have since then calmed down but I do still use the mods very frequently and have almost never been disappointed. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone. There are so many opportunities in this game. Whether you just want to role-play with your friends or farm solo, its all up to you! So yeah, please check this game out its awesome. Been playing Farm Sim since 2015, and they just keep getting better! The quality of life improvements from 2019-now is outstanding. Most things are more user friendly, and the new production chains are a great asset. you can tell they pay attention to the modding community as they successfully implemented seasons into the game play which makes it much more immersive and fun to play. If you've liked Farm Sim in the past, or are just looking for a fun and relaxing game that's easy to get into, I highly recommend.

Now 62 hours of game time in and still can't recommend this game enough. The Platinum Expansion is well worth the money!


1/11/24 Now at 400 something hours and still really love this game! Platinum Expansion is still very good, and Premium is interesting. I am not the biggest fan of root crops, they don't vibe well with my style of game play as we don't really grow them in my area, but I do like the continued dedication to the production chains and the obvious desire to keep bringing their fanbase new things! Now if only they could put some effort into AI... the workers are better than previous but still a pain. Thanks to our great modding community, this is easily overcome with CoursePlay and AutoDrive but it would be nice to not need those... Still 10/10 for me!

Tl:Dr Giants fixed the major bugs i'd encountered, i  look forward to what Giants and the community come out with in the future. 

So, I was a little salty on my first review of this game, i believe reasonably so, given that i'd encountered 3 seperate game breaking bugs in my first couple hours, but the good news is that those 3 have been fixed ( My crops now actually grow when i plant em, Contracts now payout when i finish em,and don't just get stuck at 85% and if i have seasons turned on, they actually change and it doesn't just snow year round ). They changed the way crops work in this update of the franchise, Crops take longer to grow compared to previous versions but seem to give more liters of Crop per field and that crop is worth more at the sell point. That pans out roughly even for me but it was a surprise to find out. i look forward to seeing what the community and giants come out with.

Edit as of jan. 2024:
The game seems to be playable on a dedicated server now. Been playing 30+ hours over without any of the problems listed below. With the current price tag of 20€, I would recommend to consider buying it.


Original:

I've been playing this for hours upon hours since FS15, and it has always been riddled with bugs and crappy phsyics. All that is fine by me - it's kinda charming after all. What is not fine by me is Giants publishing a game that is not in a playable state if you want to play with your friends. 

My friends and I have tried different hosting services for our dedicated. The common theme for all of them, you ask? None of them actually lets us save the progress we make. I really want to recommend this game at this point, as multiplayer is a crucial part of the fun. 

The reports of trouble with multiplayer saving started to come in December 2021, four months ago when writing this review. In NONE of the forum threads Giants have showed any effort to tell us when it will be fix, possible work-arounds and so forth. That's not okay, not for a game charging a premium price from it's customers. 

I might change this review in the future if the issues is resolved, but for now I don't recommend anyone splashing 40€ on this game.

I'm really pleased with how FS22 turned out! I love the game and the many choices of industry you have. The game offer's a more advanced system to farm than FS-19 did. At first, this seemed like an interesting game, however...
The controls for driving are incredibly delayed and finnicky - It may be realistic for the wheels turning but it gets incredibly annoying while trying to drive around with your machines, both on roads and on fields.
If you're not someone who's a walking encyclopedia on agriculture, you will have a really REALLY hard time figuring out what to do. While in the shop, vehicles lack a description- Anything basic such as what they are used for. (I may be wrong, but I just couldn't find this information).

The tutorial (if you can even call it that) is incredibly short, and only explains the absolute basics (like steering, attaching stuff and 4 default machines), while anything beyond that, such as fertilization, seasons, map navigation, forestry, building, animals, etc. is up to you to figure out, using their completely text + image based guidebook in a menu.

I'm certain that for someone who knows a lot about farming, this game is perfect, but for a casual gamer like me, I really cannot enjoy this game. Unfortunately because of this, I refunded within an hour and a half of playing- I just couldn't figure stuff out. I know other farming sims perfect for someone who doesn't know what they're doing with nicely made tutorials, and this isn't one of them.

Fairly well polished, and quite complex and engaging. There isn't a lot of room for automation -- the AI workers aren't that smart, but there are mods to expand the automation aspect. The grind is fairly slow at first, but that's sort of expected for the Farming Simulator series.

Side note, FS23 on mobile is very similar both visually and gameplay. I wouldn't call FS23 a port of FS22, because there are no mods, it doesn't have all the controls, it has fewer machines, no contracts, the maps are different, etc. But FS23 does feel more like "FS22 lite." I prefer FS22 (this game) over FS23 (the mobile game), although FS22 has a steeper ramp-up getting started.

So, I've been plowing through Farming Simulator 22, and here's my take on it.

Let's start off with the visuals, as they definitely need work. For example, the water reflections are absolutely terrible, as there's invisible trees showing on the water.  Also, the water ripples aren't even there.  In addition, the lackluster tree designs left me scratching my head.

Character customization? More like character limitation! Wardrobe options are on the slim side, and forget about defining facial or body features. Hair choices? Limited. Color options? Unfortunately, its all limited. It's like the farm fashion police are on patrol.

Missions, oh nice! Harvesting, bailing, fertilizing, and seeding are all well and included in the game.  However, where's the liming, chaff/silage, transport missions, and weed control action as contract work?  Unfortunately, all are MIA.  Moreover, don't get me started on the realism front. Tracks and multiple wheel sets on farm tractors and implements are a great addition to the game, although field conditions don't affect the use of these features. In addition, vehicles sipping on DEF? Not in this game.  You'll have to look on a mod website for these items.

Palm tree enthusiasts, brace yourselves! Giants didn't bring palm trees to the party despite requests from the consumer, for the forestry side of the game. DLCs? appears to be somewhat limited content. Maps and vehicles are slim pickings, although there are some nice ones.

Now, the silver lining – the game nails the down-to-earth farmer experience. Planting crops, raising animals, it's all there. Yet, the real MVPs? The modders. They've transformed this game into a global agricultural extravaganza, bringing in maps, machinery, and all the gameplay tweaks that Giants missed.

In a nutshell, if you're dreaming of a serene life in the digital countryside, Farming Simulator 22 might just appeal to you. It's a chill, entertaining game with a farm-life vibe. Just be ready to rely on mods for the full farming buffet.

I've played these games sense 2015 and I hate how there really has been no change in the game at all sense. Now everyone has covered the basics in other negative reviews but this is something I wanted to go on.

Farming Simulator 2019 was the funnest one for me because of this reason: a mod map. I love to give myself as much of a realistic simulator as possible. I started on hard, and the map gave you absolutely nothing with prices of land being extremely realistic. It was a challenge and it felt real, starting with the worst equipment you could imagine barely scraping by to buy anything at all and not completely run out of money. It was hard but very rewarding and fun.

What I hate about this one is there is no challenge. You start even on the hardest difficulty with all the best tractors and 500,000 to buy a huge plot of land (And in almost all maps the land is worth absolutely nothing) already right off the bat you just won. After two harvests you have thousands. That isn't realistic you don't just start with everything. I love on simulators where you really start with nothing which is how it really is. I get having difficulty changes like easy modes for people who wanna just farm but if people want a challenge make it possible to have a challenge!

And when you want to make a challenge and you wanna start with nothing and sell the vehicles it makes it worse because then you make 600,000+ on top of the 500,000 and now you have enough to buy HUGE land and nice tractors and then after again even one or two harvests you have enough for almost anything.

Almost all mod maps are like that to. I had to spend a entire day looking for a map that didn't just give me the best harvester and tractor in the game starting.

I know i'm weird on this but I want a challenge I'm related to a farmer and farming is way more challenging and harder then this by a long shot. This game makes it a breeze I want a challenge at all.

So if your looking at this game and wanting to think, have problems, feel really rewarded, and go very sim this isn't really the one unless you find a good mod map.

There is little to no information which vehicles are intended for which action. The controls for the various machines could be greatly simplified by using both joysticks but instead it's a button combo and joystick manipulation.
Overall, I wanted to love this game, it had some elements that I just wanted so badly to enjoy but I couldn't get over the poor control setup, menu system, lack of additional helpful information about each vehicle and attachment.

If you have ever owned any prior version of this game then don't waste your money on this.  This game peaked around FS15 or FS17.  These guys keep re-selling the exact same game over and over again at full price ever since FS13, each new version having VERY minor changes which are not worth the price.  Worse is the cruft that should have been fixed long ago still lingering on from version to version.  The main map of this game is full of bugs such as invisible artifacts that you run into which then havok your equipment.  The food ratio calcuations for animal pens is still a huge mess and doesn't work properly, especially for pigs.  
I love the concept of this game and I enjoy playing these type of tycoon games, but these guys need to ditch this tired old game engine, and stop with the minimal-effort new releases which they over-charge their customers for.  Calling this a "simulator" with a straight face is more than a bit of a stretch, it is a tycoon game that needs a -serious- overhaul built with a modern game engine.  This brand new game feels like it is 10+ years old.

A satisfying, slow paced, chill game. This is a fun way to pass time and build something casually. Its oddly satisfying and surprisingly rewarding to work fields and move crops. The logging mechanics are a bit buggy but a ton of fun. This game is made much better with the addition of mods. Mods can add to automation (avoiding the redundant field work which can become boring after many hours of gameplay) as well as to the variety of machines and implements. I recommend this for players who enjoy slow paced casual gaming, pairs especially well with podcasts or audio books.
If you love farming, then get this game.

100 out of 10 stars! I really love this game and have more hours in this game than any other game I have ever played (according to steam). This game is a true open world sandbox game. Do anything you want at any time you want. This game has the best mod and community support of any game I have ever played. The developers go through and check each and every mod out and make sure it works and is up to par with their game. The mods are accessible from right in game off the main menu so no need to go to a separate site and since they are approved by the game developers you can be rest assured they work. there are thousands of mods, so many so that they are categorized into 10-15 different categories. You can get new vehicles, implements, buildings, animals and even game mechanics! The options are truly vast. most vehicles, are customizable where you can choose all kids of parts as well as colors. you can change the game mechanics through mods!  You can make this game as realistic or as fake and gamey as you choose or a balance in between as I have. The sim world is your oyster! The base game itself is excellent, however the mod support and level of mod customization makes this game unmatched in the gaming world. I know no other game that even comes close!

Title: A Harvest of Excellence - Farming Simulator 22

Rating: ★★★★★★★★★★ (10/10)

Farming Simulator 22 is a masterpiece that cultivates the very essence of virtual agriculture, delivering an unparalleled and immersive farming experience. Giants Software has outdone themselves, crafting a game that not only surpasses its predecessor but sets a new standard for the simulation genre.

Visual Splendor (10/10):
The graphics are nothing short of breathtaking. From the golden fields of wheat swaying in the wind to the meticulous detail of the machinery, every element is a visual feast. The level of realism achieved in Farming Simulator 22 is awe-inspiring, making the virtual farming world come to life.

Expansive Gameplay (10/10):
The game boasts an extensive array of crops, animals, and machinery, providing a vast playground for players to explore. Whether you're cultivating fields, raising livestock, or delving into forestry, there's always a new challenge to conquer, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting.

Realistic Simulation (10/10):
The attention to detail in the simulation is unparalleled. The physics of farming activities, weather effects, and the day-night cycle create an authentic farming atmosphere. It feels like you're not just playing a game but stepping into the boots of a real-life farmer.

In-depth Management (10/10):
Farming Simulator 22 introduces an enhanced management system, allowing players to fine-tune every aspect of their farm. From finances to crop rotation, the game encourages strategic thinking, making every decision impactful on the overall success of your virtual farm.

Multiplayer Magic (10/10):
The multiplayer mode adds a social dimension to farming, letting you collaborate with friends or other players globally. Tackling tasks together, sharing resources, and building a virtual farming community enhances the enjoyment and longevity of the game.

Modding Paradise (10/10):
The modding community has always been a strength of the Farming Simulator series, and FS22 is no exception. The game supports a vast array of mods that can be easily integrated, offering endless possibilities for customization and personalization.

Educational Value (10/10):
Farming Simulator 22 serves as an educational tool, providing insights into the intricacies of agriculture. From understanding crop growth cycles to managing resources efficiently, players can learn valuable skills that extend beyond the virtual farm.

Responsive Development Team (10/10):
The dedication of Giants Software to continuously improve and update the game is commendable. Regular patches, bug fixes, and the active engagement with the player community demonstrate a commitment to delivering a polished and enjoyable gaming experience.

Immersive Soundtrack (10/10):
The soundtrack complements the farming ambiance perfectly, with soothing tunes that enhance the immersive nature of the game. From the gentle hum of machinery to the chirping of birds, every audio detail is meticulously crafted.

Overall Excellence (10/10):
Farming Simulator 22 is a triumph, achieving excellence in every aspect of its design. Whether you're a virtual farmer or a simulation enthusiast, this game is a must-play. It not only entertains but educates, providing a wholesome gaming experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end. Giants Software has sown the seeds of gaming brilliance, and Farming Simulator 22 is the bountiful harvest we've all been waiting for.

Fundamentally, this is an ok game. I like sandbox games a lot, but the game studio has a worsening record on quality. (I am a software engineer, so know how these firms work internally.) FS19, the previous edition, was beset by bugs on release and took at least 6-12 months to become stable. This release has far more major bugs at release, and 5 months later and multiple patches, many bugs are still getting worse not better, and these aren't infrequent, minor bugs either. These are frequent, rage-quit inducing bugs.
Half of the community are really nice people, but a vocal minority are aggressively unpleasant fanboys who believe Giants are perfect beings from another dimension.
I only bought FS22 to play one mod map - Calmsden Farm, which is beautiful. If that map hadn't been released, I'd have not bought this game. Maybe I shouldn't have anyway, but I'll try and get my moneys worth. It might be stable by summer 22.

Update (Dec 23): Some bugs fixed, most not. I give up - never again.

Dec 2023 Update - I'm over the summer sale fiasco, changed recommendation back to "yes" - this is my therapy :)

edit - It now appears that there is a "complete your collection" bundle, which offers a degree of savings to those who purchased the base game prior to the announcement of the premium edition / 2023 summer sale. Still think this was more likely a reflexive response to community reaction vice deliberate planning though...and if it was the latter, that's probably worse (imo)...

TL;DR - Since I paid (near) full price for the base game around launch, I'm not able to benefit from the current sale...  Nor the previous one when the Platinum Edition was released...  See the pattern emerging?

I really want to write good things about this game, having been with the franchise since FS15.  While I have not subscribed to the new season pass model (I despise it, personally, and several of the DLC are either highly niche or functionally repaints of existing elements in game), I have enjoyed the updated gameplay, new production chains, maps and especially the FS22 Platinum Expansion (I like logging, I find it fun!). 

However, the increasingly aggressive monetization and what feels like increasingly frequent hollow/empty promises is slowly killing the game for me (sadly).

The 2023 Summer Sale is just a giant slap in the face to long-term supporters. 

This is the opportune time to pick up the game if you are new - you can get the base game AND both season passes (functionally, almost everything released and planned at this time, look for the "Farming Simulator 22: Premium Edition" bundle) for roughly the same price as we who already bought the game (and supported the developer!) have to pay for ONE of the season passes... Not even a discounted "Complete your Collection"-style bundle made available, nor are any of the season passes or DLC on sale individually (except the recently announced Premium Expansion, which has a fairly typical 10% PRE-release discount).  

I fully support monetization of DLCs in this franchise (they have a steady pacing of releases, some of which are free), but the overall value seems to be decreasing - and so to has the frequency and scale of sales. 

There is also the highly controversial Kubota Pack, which is required for multiplayer passenger capability - something modders have provided in previous iterations for free, could have (and seriously, should have) been included in the base game has now been functionally paywalled. 

Come on, Giants - you used to be one of the developers that others were compared against. Maybe your publisher has gotten too greedy? It's not too late...

One of my lowest gaming moments is spiking a PS4 controller playing Elden Ring (like a child) but the frustration I feel playing this game is far greater. Literally every decision you make can cost you very, very dearly in terms of resources or (more importantly) your time and there's very few ways to learn other than failure or wikis.

This might be what people enjoy about the game, in which case I'm happy for you, but I actually enjoy games that force you to work through difficult sim situations and I actually enjoy the tedium of repeated steps towards accomplishing a slightly bigger step in turn working towards a reward that only makes it slightly easier for you to repeat the same exact loop over and over and honestly, this game is too much for me, any decision beyond cultivating a neighbour's field or weeding my own 3 fields is likely to set me back and I just can't be bothered.

Also having shop items in non-alphabetical order (and not having a search option) makes me want to tear my eyes out.

This game gives you lots of options for how you want to play.  Cereal crops, animals, root crops, logging, cotton, sugarcane,  each map you play can be totally different, you can do basic farming or ultra-realistic and challenging.  

The mods and Giants support of them are what really make this game great though.  There's a thriving community of modders constantly making new equipment, tractors, trucks, maps, placeables, productions, etc...  

Want to capture the feeling you had growing on on the family farm?   Grew up in a city and never been on a farm and curios?  This game appeals to all looking for a more relaxed, creative and open game.  Multiplayer is where this really gets fun, working with your friends or a content creator's multiplayer server is a blast!  Highly recommended

[h1]Cultivating, Plowing, Seeding, Spraying, Weeding, Harvesting...you name it. It´s all up for grabs and it´s up to you to choose what to do and when its best to do it.[/h1]

Ask any farmer what they love the most about their profession and you will get different answers, but all of them will agree on one thing...theres nothing better than the smell of freshly tilled earth.
In Farmer Simulator 22 you wont get to experince that but you can do pretty much [b]anything[/b] a farmer does while on the field.
[b]Truth be told it´s not much of a jump from FS19 as FS19 was from FS17 but it has its charms.[/b]  
New crops to choose from (Olives, Grapes and Sorghum), the Seasons mechanic is now implemented on the game itself, field care is now a more serious thing (rock removal, lime , weeds, compaction etc) and Huge maps.
Offical brands of machinery and implements make a appearence on FS22 as usual with the addition of a couple of newcomers. A point to mention is the lack of some machines present on previous games (i miss the old Case 1680 Axial Flow combines and some others) even though you can get them using mods its not the same thing as when the makers of the game honour the classics. But who knows? Maybe Giants has some surprises in store for future DLC´s.

One brand new thing is [b]Production Chains[/b]. It basically gives you a follow up on virtually anything you produce/harvest. Wheat to Bread, Barley to Beer, Milk to Butter or Cheese and so on.

Although it looks and feels amazing, this is not the kind of game that will appeal to every player, not everyone can stand the slow pace of farming, the time it takes to plow or cultivate a field or the careful planning of your campaign to hit the market next year with fields giving good yields.

Its a great game to relax and enjoy at the end of the day and with the plus of learning new things about the rich world of farming. If you are tired of the endless grind, leaderboard climbing and rank crashing routine of whatever you are playing, then get adventurous and give Farming Simulator 22 a try.

Farming Simulator 22 is an absolute gem in the simulation world. With stunning visuals, realistic mechanics, and a wealth of new features like diverse crops and enhanced farming activities, it's an immersive experience that keeps you engaged. Whether you're a seasoned player or new to farming sims, its accessibility and multiplayer mode make it a must-play for anyone seeking a deeply satisfying gaming experience.
Awesome game. Nice mods and DLC's.

It's more then great, buy it!

Giants Software has really stepped up and improved Farming Simulator, not least that there is more to do more than cultivate and harvest. You can start your own production the ones you choose for your farm.

You can clearly see that the developers have focused so that even beginners understand what to use what for each step. Clarify and categorize in settings and in the shop. Which is fun to see a big improvement on.

The graphics are also an improvement on if you compare previous Farming Simulator games. From better textures on crops, soil everything. Better light and shadows. There is also support for Nvidia DLSS, DLAA and AMD FSR (FidelityFX Super Resolution). Which is worth turning on.

When you choose to play multiplayer and you are on the server and waiting for others to join, you will notice a much appreciated improvement and that is synchronization. It goes twice as fast now when someone joins. You barely have time to blink.

I recommend playing with an ultrawide screen to get the maximum gaming experience, rather than playing on a widescreen where you do not get the same gaming experience at all.

Would I recommend this game? Yes Absolutely. But I recommend getting all the DLC as well because there is more content in them than just playing the base game, such as new machines, tools but also a lot for forestry that makes it more fun to play.
900+ hours kind of speaks for itself, but it truly is the best iteration of the series to date.

Farming Simulator 22: Where Virtual Crops Trump Actual Chores

If you've ever dreamed of trading your city slicker lifestyle for the soothing sounds of virtual tractor engines and the sweet scent of pixelated manure, then Farming Simulator 22 is the game for you! Finally, a game that lets you experience the thrill of planting, plowing, and harvesting without breaking a sweat or developing a sudden love for early mornings.

First off, the graphics are so realistic that I almost found myself reaching for a virtual sunscreen during those sunny in-game days. The attention to detail is impeccable, from the mesmerizing sway of the pixelated wheat fields to the way the chickens cluck with pixel-perfect precision. It's like a high-stakes game of "Is this hay bale real or just a bunch of pixels?" Spoiler alert: They're pixels.

The game offers an unparalleled sense of accomplishment. Forget climbing the corporate ladder; here, the real challenge is mastering the art of tractor maneuvering without accidentally running over your virtual crops. It's a delicate dance of digital agriculture that makes you question why you never pursued a career in pixelated farming.

Multiplayer mode adds a whole new dimension to the game. Ever wanted to have a virtual barn-raising with your friends? Now you can, and it's surprisingly more entertaining than it sounds. Who knew that coordinating the virtual harvest with your pals could be both hilarious and oddly satisfying?

But be warned, Farming Simulator 22 may cause an unexpected interest in agriculture. You might catch yourself browsing real estate listings for farms, contemplating a career change to become a digital farmer turned real farmer. It's a slippery slope from virtual crops to actual crops, and before you know it, you'll be debating the merits of different types of manure with your neighbors. Farming Simulator 22: Where plowing fields meets planting the seed of a new hobby!

-Sure, there are some aspects of the game that need a little fix, but overall I think Giants did a great job. 
-Love the game, love the community, incredible mod developers and the recently added crossplay feature..

I do not think that the tutorial is thorough enough for a player who has never played the previous games. I did a few saves to try it out to start and after that I got the hang of it. I recommend checking out all the panels in the options screen because I had completely missed that there was a contracts section. Doing contracts is the easiest way to make money while you wait to harvest during different seasons. I also recommend checking out the different tools and equipment (and the combinations for each) thoroughly before leasing or buying. In my first few saves I got a bit eager and thought I could just return the product if it was the wrong piece of equipment (which you can but you don't get the initial up front leasing cost back). Doing this a few times can drastically affect your finances so I would definitely double check you are using the right equipment first. 

The actual game is beautiful and very peaceful. You can stay very busy and not even notice you've been playing for a few hours. I have played both on my PlayStation and now PC, and I prefer the PC. The controls just make more sense and I find it easier to navigate the help section (which is super important for first time players). The overall variety included in this game is insane giving it a high replay-ability. The three maps are big enough to play for weeks at a time on each and since the seasons are forever changing, you could just play one map forever. It's also more than just planting and harvesting. You can open up restaurants, farmers markets, and export your product. You can build up your farm with advancements like more barns, silos, or solar panels. 

Overall, I highly recommend this game to people who like to build and create. Games that this reminded me of included city skylines, sims, minecraft, and stardew valley.

First and foremost, this game offers an impressive variety of farming activities. From cultivating fields and planting crops to tending livestock and managing your farm's resources, there's a whole lot to dig into. You'll find an extensive collection of farming equipment and machinery at your disposal, which can be both exciting and overwhelming, especially for newcomers.

Now, I must admit, this game isn't for those seeking adrenaline-pumping action. It's more of a tranquil and methodical experience, mirroring the pace of real farming. Patience is key here, and if you have a fondness for simulation games that let you take your time, you're in for a serene treat. Farming Simulator 22 is a great choice for players who appreciate simulation games and have a penchant for the agricultural life.

Well, well, well, where to begin with Farming Simulator 22? This game has been a wild ride right from the off. Let me tell you, for $39.99, it’s worth every penny – or cent – for the hours of entertainment, bewilderment, and outright hilarity it offers.

First up, the graphics. Ah, the beautiful, crisp, breathtaking graphics. I’ve been around the digital block a few times and I can tell you, I've never seen corn sway in the breeze quite like it does in FS22. With scenery scoring an easy 10/10, the maps are so realistic, you can practically smell the fresh country air and feel the chill of the winter snow. Elmcreek, Haut-Beyleron, and Erlengrat – each one a picturesque jewel in the farming crown.

Now, onto the machines – the heart and soul of any farming enterprise. They start off gleaming, pristine, and before you know it, they're caked in dirt, just like the real deal. Rain, snow, all that beautiful stuff. They’ve thought of everything. The animations are something to behold – watching a crop sparayer folding and unfolding is an oddly satisfying way to spend an afternoon.

Beware of setting an unfortunate username! The game's character editor seems to develop an unhealthy attachment to your first choice, forcing you to change it every time you log in. I’m seriously considering making "UsernameRegret" my permanent moniker.

And let's talk about the DLCs. Yes, some are fantastic – the Göweil Pack and Platinum Expansion, absolute steals at $9.99 and $19.99 respectively, and who can resist the charm of the Zetor 25 K for a mere $0.99? But the others, well, let's just say it feels more like a 'donation' to the developers than a value-add to the game.

However, not all is bountiful in the fields of Farming Simulator 22. I've got some beef with the size of the maps. I mean, if I'm in a pickup truck, it shouldn't take me just 15 minutes to get from one end to the other while respecting speed limits. This isn't a Sunday drive, it's farming!

And then there are the AI workers, oh what a joy they are. You'd think they were driving a Ferrari across Monte Carlo the way they charge for their services! Picture this: you task them with the simple job of hauling sugar beets from one end of our admittedly small map to the other. They putter along at the blistering speed of a sloth on vacation, somewhere between 20 and 39 mph, and for this high-octane thrill ride, they bleed you dry. That's right, they liberate $100 of your hard-earned in-game currency for every 10 in-game minutes they spend at the wheel. At this rate, they'd drive any player into bankruptcy faster than you can say "Farming Simulator 22"!

And would it kill them to animate a door opening? We've mastered teleportation in FS22 – a feat yet unachieved in the real world, mind you – because you simply phase into your tractor's cab. Meanwhile, community modders have done what seems impossible for the devs, making walk-around interiors a reality!

And then, there's the infamous 'Black Sky Bug'. Picture this: after two or three wonderful farming sessions, the once clear blue sky turns pitch black - both day and night. It's like you've been suddenly transported to a parallel universe where physics doesn't exist, and neither do the wheels of your vehicles. You'll find yourself operating a fleet of floating machinery. The trains? They pull a Houdini on you. Even the hardest-working farmer can't load an invisible train!

Now, the process to fix this would make a NASA engineer break into a cold sweat: first, you must perform a ritual of deleting save files, then exorcise your system of the game and its DLCs. After a couple of computer restarts sprinkled in for good measure, you have to cleanse your computer's cache. Once all this is done, it's time to download everything again like you're living your very own Groundhog Day. Seriously, did I sign up to be a farmer or an IT technician?

Last but not least, a shout-out to the game's support team for their unresponsiveness. I reported this black sky, vehicle tires disappearing bug back in September 2022. It’s July 2023 now, and I'm still waiting. Hey, at least it’s comforting to know that the simulated farming world is just as full of delays and ignored messages as the real one. 

All in all, Farming Simulator 22 is a worthwhile venture for both seasoned and novice virtual farmers, offering hours of unique, engaging gameplay that will keep you hooked, despite its occasional hiccups.

10/31/2023:
And of course, when I decided to give it another whirl, the devs had zapped away the WindowedFullscreen option. Marvelous! So now my options are squinting at a window the size of a postage stamp, or going full screen and playing digital whack-a-mole with my windows every time I dare to multitask. It's like choosing between a flat tire and running out of gas – either way, you're not going anywhere fast. Let's just say, it adds a whole new level of 'challenge' to the game – one I never signed up for.

And then, as if by some dark magic, full-screen mode turns my in-game camera into a carnival ride. Swinging it to the right summons a ghostly cursor, which I was pretty sure was a myth, to play pinball on the screen edges, effectively putting my camera moves on timeout. As if that wasn't enough of a throwback, my fancy Legion Lenovo 5i has decided to cosplay as a vintage computer, stuttering like it's trying to communicate via Morse code and ditching anti-aliasing like a bad habit. Meanwhile, my once-crisp 5K visuals have devolved into a nostalgic pixel art exhibit. Ah, the "good" old days!

Also, the game's support team still has not responded.

Riding into the field with the power of countless horses, a murder of crows flies off in all directions scattered and cawing at your presence.
You know not what they were eating, and it doesn't matter.
The sun glints off the blades of your implements, polished and cleaned in preparation for the task at hand.
It is a lonely business, but necessary.
You are here for a gruelling and dirty task that is intended to ensure the continuation of life - if it were not for the actions you take today, countless others may starve and die.
You briefly recall the harrowing tales that brought you to this point.
That which is before you, you had cared for. Watched them grow, mature; even worried for them in the storms.
Although you had said it was the last straw just a year before, truly you knew you would be here again, and for the same reason.
The sound of screetching and metal grinding into action, you start chopping off their heads.
This is the purpose for which they were raised.
Row after row falls before you as you ride on.
Ah yes.
The wheat harvest is upon us again.

My Review of Farming Simulator 2022
Currently sitting at 685 hours of game time without mods

Pros:
Wide selection of farming equipment and attachments for said equipment from various manufacturers like Massey Ferguson, Claas, Fendt. Pottinger.
AI Makes taking care of many fields a blast
Machinery sounds like it would IRL
You can Boycott John Deere and never have to use a single thing from them without ruining your game play or limiting it
A month into one save and i barely managed to own all the farm plots
Contracts are amazing and help pad the pocket and cut out idle time.
It has snow and snow plows.

Cons:
It has the simulator wonkyness that come with most other "simulators"
John Deere Equipment
The AI is well AI and will derp about.
the AI will miss spots on your farm if objects are close to the field

Overall if you think you want to be a farming or express a hint that you like farming you should check out the game.

Farming Simulator 22 (FS22), the latest installment in the beloved franchise, earns my 6/10 rating. With enhanced graphics, an expanded roster of vehicles, and a more immersive farming experience, it caters well to simulation enthusiasts. The addition of seasonal cycles adds depth, reflecting real-world farming challenges. However, the game's mechanics might feel familiar to series veterans, lacking significant innovation. The modding community continues to enrich the gameplay, offering diverse content. Despite its incremental improvements, FS22 delivers a solid farming simulation experience, making it a worthwhile choice for fans, though it might not offer a groundbreaking leap for long-time players.

Cultivating Success and Relaxation - Farming Simulator 22 Review

Farming Simulator 22 takes the plow to a whole new level, offering a deeply engaging and authentic agricultural experience that's not only a game but a therapeutic journey into the world of farming. If you're looking for a laid-back, yet incredibly rewarding simulation, this title is an absolute gem and deserves a place in your gaming library.

The heart of Farming Simulator 22 lies in its commitment to realism and detail. It brings the everyday life of a farmer to your screen, offering you a chance to plant and harvest a wide variety of crops, manage livestock, and tend to all aspects of farm life. The level of depth is nothing short of remarkable, with every aspect of farming recreated with meticulous attention to detail.

The game's graphics and presentation are striking, creating a visually stunning and immersive farming world. The environments, landscapes, and even the equipment are beautifully rendered, adding to the overall enjoyment of the game.

One of the highlights of Farming Simulator 22 is the wide range of equipment at your disposal. Whether you're into plowing fields, harvesting, or animal husbandry, there's a diverse collection of tractors, combines, and tools to help you get the job done. The satisfaction of efficiently managing your farm with the right equipment and seeing it thrive is a truly rewarding experience.

The game's extensive single-player mode offers a series of missions and challenges to help you get started in the world of farming. Additionally, there's a cooperative multiplayer mode that lets you team up with friends to tackle farming tasks together, making for an enjoyable and social experience.

While Farming Simulator 22 is rooted in realism, it's also a relaxing and meditative game. It's a perfect way to unwind and escape from the hectic pace of daily life. The game's soothing soundtrack and the rhythm of farming activities can be almost therapeutic, making it a fantastic choice for those seeking a calming gaming experience.

In conclusion, Farming Simulator 22 is a game that excels in delivering an authentic, detailed, and visually impressive farming experience. It's not just a game; it's a tranquil journey into the world of agriculture. Whether you're a fan of simulation games or simply looking for a way to relax and unwind, Farming Simulator 22 is well worth the recommendation. Prepare to till the soil, sow the seeds, and reap the rewards of your virtual farm in a game that's both rewarding and peaceful.

You know, I've hit 500 hours on this game in the last nearly 2 years, and I figure it's time for a review. So let's get into it.

There are alot of people dogging on this game for just being another repeat - which it is. I have to agree with this. But also remember the fact there's a ton of new features and polishing with this. This game feels like a whole different franchise just from the polishing. There isn't random clipping textures, holes in equipment, 144p looking wear textures on equipment.. This game looks good. Like really good. Though if I'm honest this game is what 19 needed to be.

Big features with this version are the addition of built in seasons which you can customize to your liking, and while it may not be Realismus seasons, it's pretty damn good. I really enjoy playing with it. Also the maps have tons of live features now, so for example when a new DLC is approaching the billboards and signs start showing info for that DLC, and during seasons, you'll see barbecues in the summer, halloween deco in October, and snowmen/Christmas deco in December. It's a really nice addition, and finally the maps feel like they have some life. As for the maps themselves, you have Elmcreek which is based in the Midwest region of the USA, hard to place exactly where but I would say Iowa/Indiana/Illinois area, just based on the overall area. There is also a french map, that I think is pretty bland and disappointing, and I couldn't say where it's based but I would say it's the western part. There is also Erlengrat which is a Swiss map from FS19's Alpine DLC. It's the exact same map and while I love playing on it, it does have some FPS issues and can be very confusing if you don't understand the concept of the map.

Next we move onto equipment. Here's where it gets wild. The brands they brought into this release, among small things everybody has wanted, is insane. There has to be a minimum of 25 new brands in this game and at least 100 new machines not counting any DLC. It's truly insane the equipment selection in this game. There's some weak points, like mid size seeders and cultivators, but there's ways around it. You of course have plenty of mods, or you can stick with smaller stuff and just deal with the extra time taken. I do a mix of both. There's some tractors that have US and EU spec options, all crawler tractors and harvesters have 3D tracks, interiors are fully animated.. There's an insane jump in this version that 19 doesn't have. Yes 19 had some stupid nice tractors but not all. You could see the recycled stuff compared to the new stuff, in this version even the recycled equipment has all the up to date features. It's truly another level of attention to detail. Not to mention loaders and such now make a bang when lowered fully, new hydraulic sounds, new attach sounds.. And don't forget manual transmissions. While the implementation of manuals is pretty garbage, it's still one more thing this game was severely lacking in older versions. It's only weird on some vehicles, on some it works fine. All in all having this feature in the base game is a huge jump even if it's implemented terribly.

In terms of the farming aspect, it's pretty much the same, however there are some small differences. With Seasons enabled, you can only plant and harvest in certain months of the year, which adds just a little more realism. Crop growth is no longer randomized. It takes a set amount of months to grow whether you have Seasons on or off. For example wheat takes 10 months, and potatoes take 5. The plant/harvest chart reflects this. Turning off the seasons just makes it where you plant whenever and harvest whenever. There is also parallox occlusion mapping, which makes anything rows look 3D even though they aren't. While it may not be as good as true 3D ground, it looks extremely nice. There are also grape vines and olive groves now, and the respective equipment to harvest these. They are annoying, but fun. There are no new animals in this version. Aside from these it's pretty much the same old farming system from 19.

Now on to landscaping and build mode. The landscaping mode remains mostly unchanged from FS19 aside from being way more polished and working a whole lot better, among new ground materials. Foliage and ground are separated, and you can do some truly wild stuff through the landscaping tool. As for build mode, this is a new addition that effectively took the Placeables menu and turned it into it's own mode. There's a ton of new lists and menus, you can place almost anything. Fences, animal pens, decorations, productions.. Almost anything you can place, and if you don't find it there, guaranteed there's a mod for it. You can literally build a map from bare nothing if you want using just the build and terrain tools. It's pretty cool.

Coming to the end you have stuff such as the modhub, crossplay support, multiplayer, and other finishing touches. The multiplayer is an absolute disaster. I'm not talking in people, I'm talking the server side. It's been pretty broken since the game's release, and only minimal improvements over time. They consolidated the 6 individual servers down to 1 massive server, and on busy days, forget MP entirely. It overloads in no time flat, and if you do get in, have fun staying in. It's a DISASTER. As for the in game modhub, not much is changed, though you no longer have to restart after getting mods, they just automatically install and you're all set. There's a good selection of mods, both PC only and crossplay, and that brings us to crossplay. You can play with someone on a console, from PC, as long as you have matching CROSSPLAY mods. Not just any mod is crossplay, only certain ones are. Because consoles are so limited on space and licensing, only non licensed (and brands already in-game) are allowed. This will never be changed. If you want a bunch of cool modded stuff, buy a PC and do the game the right way. Consoles are NOT meant for this type of game.

All in all, this game is a 7/10. There are a ton of good features about it, it's extremely stable and seems to just work all times unlike the last 2 versions, and there are a few bad features. The biggest thing to me is I feel like a lot of the features of this should have been for FS19 and in this version they should've focused on 3D ground, more realistic harvesting, more crops and other things people have been asking about for years. But maybe the next iteration will have a few of these. Though this is a healthy addition, and while 19 was a ton of fun and I enjoyed it, this is a MUCH more polished game. 19 was constantly crashing, full of broken equipment, missing textures, bugged maps and more. This one has hardly any bugs. Even when it released almost everything worked, and within 2 weeks the game had no bugs. The only real issue is the multiplayer, but it works if you understand when to use it for a good experience. All in all this game is a very polished and fun to play game. The price tag is a little high, but it is worth it. The attention to detail in this version is worth the extra money. You won't notice it until you play but they went over the top with details on everything. It's pretty awesome.

Hope this was a helpful review that talks someone into this game. I know I've gotten my moneys worth and will continue to do so. This is a really good game in the series. Let's hope the next one is even better.
