Updated 10/13/23

(Summary at bottom)
NOT a reskinned FS19. I have about 650 hours on FS19 and I can most certainly say this is much better in many ways, and many things have been completely overhauled. 

- Sounds have had a major overhaul, makes the game feel more realistic and immersive.
- A few minor realism additions, like visual gear-shifting, cab suspension, etc.
- More placeables than ever, including sheds with working doors, refuel stations, seed & fert tanks, etc. Fences, lights, and other decor too, to brighten up your farm a bit.
- Many new brands, and more tire brand options. Also license plates for equipment and vehicles.
- Character customization. Imo, not the best, graphics and general proportions look weird, but hey, better than before.
- Better organized XML files. Much more easier on the eyes compared to FS17, and easier to find things such as the money value. I don't need to use ctrl+f anymore, I can just scroll. (Speaking of XML editing, instead of editing the careerSavegame.xml file like FS17 & FS19 to edit your cash, here you need to edit farms.xml file instead in the same folder, careerSavegame.xml is only for appearance in the main menu.)
- Better organized shop UI, not to mention the UI overall. Imo, the weird blue fade on the speedometer/tachometer reminds me of those old games, and I wish they had just instead updated the FS19 one.
- An actual American-based map. Major improvement from Ravenport and Goldcrest Valley, feels more of the true american countryside thanks to that new office here in the U.S. that Giants got a while ago.
- Buying used equipment. Great for starting a farm on a tight budget, and in multiplayer you can buy other farm's sold vehicles. Wish there was more than 5 at a time though.
- Vehicle gearbox. Not required if you don't want to use it, but I like it. A wee bit confusing at times however, I'm used to the way you shift in American Truck Simulator, but this is different. Not bad, maybe needs to be tweaked a bit. Will note that it's sometimes buggy, especially with mods.
- Obviously graphics, you won't really notice a huge jump between FS19 and FS22 as the major jump of the franchise was between FS17 and FS19, but there are some noticeable changes. Also, 3D tracks on tractors. No more jpeg tracks.
- Seasons. I don't like playing so realistic to the point I have to wait time for the proper planting and harvesting time, but there's an option to make it so the seasons are just visual only. 
- Multiplayer Voice Chat, very useful.

Now, there are of course many bugs with the game, and some features missing since it got released not too long ago. 

Some rather aggravating bugs/missing features are:
- Landscaping, a tad bit annoying with the camera and movement. There's no snapping things to a certain rotation, and the camera angle is from a bird's eye view that swoops down instead of zooming in, which is rather annoying when trying to line things up together. There's also no sprinting like in FS17 (idk about the others)
- AI workers. We all know from previous FS games that the AI is notorious, especially in FS17. Here, there have been some improvements, and with the addition of AI being able to drive vehicles to and fro, that's really useful, but again, very buggy. The classic 'Helper F is blocked by an object!' pops up every now and then, you tab over and there's nothing in it's way. Lately, on modded maps, the AI sometimes will just sit there doing nothing. Possibly just a mod-side issue. 
- Buildings, most notably the farmhouse. If you look into the windows, it's just a copied .jpeg of a weird looking kitchen with yellow cabinets and a granite looking wall. I'm sure Giants will add in an interior at some point, I don't want jpeg interiors like FS13 & FS17. Also, you cannot interact with/enter any existing buildings/sheds/barns on the farms on the land you purchase. I sure hope that gets changed.(note: kinda sorta fixed? some sheds you can enter)

Bugs TL;DR:
- Landscaping (Controls & viewing angles are awkward)
- AI Driving/Transport (Blocked by nothing, drives the wrong path or drives in circles')
- didn't note this but general physics, collisions, and the gearbox still need to be tuned.

TL;DR:

There are many bugs, I hope they'll be fixed before the next year. But there are also many improvements from previous FS games, as someone who's played FS13 (Xbox 360), 17 (Steam), and 19 (Epic Games).

At this time, with the amount of bugs/missing features in the game, you can go ahead and buy it if you want. I managed to snag a deal with the season passes where I got both for like $30, damn good deal, would NOT recommend paying full price for each individual DLC.

I have not tested everything, and I have not played every map. I do not have all of the bugs and missing features listed, I will update this review as I come across more notable bugs, missing features, and changes from previous FS games.

Again, this is a newly released game, so unless Giants decides to not fix these issues/keep them removed like EA did with Battlefield 2042, then I will change this review as needed.

11/24/21 Update

So you can use Q & E to switch between the license plate types, yet when you're typing in your custom license plate and you need to press Q or E, it switches the license plate type. They do have an on-screen keyboard I assume for consoles, but I really don't want to *click, move mouse (repeat 8 more times)* every single time I have to put in a license plate. My way to bypass this is make sure the color selection is highlighted when you start typing.

The field care addon is nice, more stuff to do with Grain farming. I haven't really played around with that yet.

Graphics for working the fields look much better, but when the field state changes (harvested to cultivated, to plowed, etc) is still very noticeable and jittery, a bit annoying as it is ruining the immersion a little.

Pallet physics have improved a ton, however, but they do still slide around imo a wee bit too easily.

Bigbags! Can easily pick them up with anything with forks, and you can feel that you're picking up a heavy item. They have realistic physics, so that's nice.

12/31/21 Update

- Pre-Placed Buildings can now be deleted off of farms.
- The issue with the semi truck axles acting weird is now fixed. They drive much smoother now.

4/12/22 Update:

- Character customization is saved to the last customized option.
- License Plates are also saved the same way.
- Updated/revised entire review

9/9/22 Update:

Revised entire review again, clarified some things, and removed some stuff that didn't need to be here to make room because of the damn review character limit.

10/11/23 Update:

Fine tuned the review a little bit, moved a few notable things from previous updates to the main category, blablabla. I don't think I can do much more for this review, especially with the character limit.

This game is great for passing time and can have moments where you can enjoy yourself, however the AI and some of the mechanics of the game are very outdated. You'll often find yourself not being able to trust the AI to do a task on a field whilst you work on another task. The AI in this game can and will randomly break. You often run the risk of the AI either not doing the task properly, not behaving correctly (driving around in circles or going over the same area multiple times wasting valuable funds) or stating a task has been finished but when you get to the vehicle, it has randomly stopped in the middle of a field and with crop destruction active, you'll instantly lose all the crops you could have had by driving it out of the field to start again. Don't get me started on the AI for the traffic. Players are advised to get into a habit of turning traffic off.

I wish there was a way to make a neutral or a luke warm review. FS22 does do somethings better than previous titles. However the improvements are massively overshadowed by the downgrades. In FS19 Realism modding made an absolute masterpiece with there Seasons Mod. In FS22 Giants half baked it into the game as for the other half? your SOL. NO easily changeable Geos, NO temperature based seeding requirements, No need to properly store products for winter, NO double cropping. NO spring wheat?!? They basically washed everything interesting out of the seasons mod leaving behind very very basic gameplay. Also you have to pay to delete fields. Your telling me if something get's left alone nature wouldn't take it over? If only there was a good way to simulate that... Like the roller....that was in previous titles.

Edit* - I have quite a few issues with this game and the fact that Giant's has turned a blind eye to each of these. 
- Multiplayer servers are a pain to get set up and running correctly. I didn't have many issues last year but recently, the savegames I've set up are not populating correctly for people to join and/or doesnt show up in a timely manner (45 minutes+ to show up with constant refresh)
- Cannot directly connect to a server IP so it makes it time consuming just to host a game for friends to play on. I don't know why this isn't a feature since so many people have requested it. Giant's refuses to implement this. 
- I've had a bug since day one with refilling units. I need to disconnect and reconnect the implement to get the refill option to show. Two different computers, mod free and modded, fresh installation of game. Seems like I'm not the only one and those bug reports have gone unanswered. 

If you choose to play this by yourself, sure its good. If you want to play with friends, save your money until they decide to get with the times and add requested features. Giants = EA Games.

Farming Simulator 22 is an absolute gem of a game for anyone who has ever dreamed of running their own farm. From the moment I started playing, I was completely immersed in the world of agriculture, and I have nothing but positive things to say about this game.

First and foremost, the graphics in Farming Simulator 22 are stunning. The attention to detail in the landscapes, crops, and machinery is truly impressive. Whether it's the way the sun sets over your fields or the realistic weather effects, every aspect of the game is visually appealing and contributes to the immersive farming experience.

The gameplay itself is incredibly satisfying. Managing your farm, planting and harvesting crops, tending to livestock, and expanding your operations is both challenging and enjoyable. The addition of new crops and the ability to produce and sell various products adds depth to the gameplay, keeping you engaged for hours on end.

One of the standout features of Farming Simulator 22 is the extensive selection of machinery and equipment. With a wide range of tractors, combines, plows, and other vehicles at your disposal, you have the tools needed to customize your farm and work efficiently. The realism in how these machines handle and function adds a layer of authenticity that farming enthusiasts will appreciate.

The game also offers a great multiplayer mode, allowing you to collaborate with friends in building and managing your virtual farms. It's a fantastic way to experience the joys and challenges of farming together, making it a social experience that can be both fun and educational.

The developers have listened to the feedback from the community and have made significant improvements in Farming Simulator 22, making it more accessible and enjoyable for both newcomers and long-time fans of the series. The tutorial system is comprehensive, making it easier for newcomers to get started, while the experienced players will still find plenty of depth and challenge.

In conclusion, Farming Simulator 22 is an outstanding simulation game that offers a truly authentic and enjoyable farming experience. With its stunning graphics, realistic gameplay, extensive machinery options, and multiplayer capabilities, it's a game that keeps you coming back for more. Whether you're a farming enthusiast or just looking for a unique and relaxing gaming experience, I wholeheartedly recommend giving Farming Simulator 22 a try. It's a game that celebrates the joys of agriculture and provides countless hours of entertainment and satisfaction.

Farming Simulator's multiplayer system is an absolute train wreck, and I wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy. From the moment you enter the multiplayer mode, it's clear that this game's online experience was designed by someone who has never played a multiplayer game in their life.

First off, the matchmaking system is an exercise in frustration. It seems to have a mind of its own, often pairing you with players who have vastly different objectives or playstyles. Want to focus on efficient farming and cooperation? Tough luck! You'll end up with a group of trolls who sabotage your efforts, turning your virtual farm into a chaotic mess.

The lag in multiplayer is mind-boggling. You'd think that in this day and age, a game could handle a few players on a virtual farm without constant stuttering and disconnections. But no, expect to spend more time watching loading screens and dealing with lag spikes than actually enjoying the game.

Communication with other players is another disaster. There's no in-game voice chat, which means you're stuck typing messages in a clunky chat box while trying to harvest your crops or tend to your livestock. It's a recipe for frustration and miscommunication.

Overall, Farming Simulator's multiplayer system is a complete and utter mess. If you value your sanity and want a cooperative farming experience, look elsewhere. This game's multiplayer is nothing short of a steaming pile of manure.

Having played FS17 & FS19 for hundreds of hours I have been watching FS22 and finally decided to purchase.  However, I have requested a refund.  In just under 2 hours I discovered that the in-game AI helpers do not work with any consistency. In the Elmcreek map 2 of the first 3 fields (the ones you get as a beginning farmer) would not work with the AI helper seeding the field.  They would start (sometimes) and then stop at the end of the first pass sown the field.  I'd start them again driving the first little bit and then hired the helper (as some have suggested as a fix). They might go two passes back and forth and then would stop again.  I speculated that CoursePlay might work instead of using the base game AI hired workers but was running out of time to try this before 2 hour limit expired for refund.  However, even if CP worked you should not have to use a mod or a work around to use a very basic and important feature of the base game.  And I know that the AI helpers may not always work perfectly. On the various forums used by players I found many comments about this problem so this has been a known issue for a long time. This feature is such a part of my basic game play that I would have been frustrated over and over again with it not working. This should have been fixed years ago.  Maybe it would be better to work on known bugs rather than DLC's...  I hate to leave a negative review on a game I've enjoyed for so many hours over lots of years but people need to know this feature in this game may not work as expected.

It is now possible to hire AI workers to complete contracts without driving to the contract field.

Overall Score: neutral(for 13 eur) I wouldn't pay full price knowing what i know now.

Game is playable... But sooo much better with bunch of mods(a lot of mods and Reshade), like realism and grid snap, extend lights etc.. lots of QOL mods out there.( and only reason i keep playing because of mods)

Vanilla game is.. an arcady stuff( but u got to keep excel spreadsheet), and there is more than one way to cheese(create new farm and transfer all money), no real goal or challenge even on hard( this changes with some mods that make it a lot harder and more punishing to do stupid or shortcut things). I did not encounter many bugs, but a lot of "why can't I do this!?" like empty water tank anywhere, not wrap grass bales, add only little to TMR mixer, etc...

Simulation( as in the title lol):
No dew in mornings, no moisture consideration or quality of the crop. Only thing is that you get less which is not always the case, you get low quality but the same amount and then it requires further processing. no clogging of machines, no breakdown. Could talk more about harvesting in high humidity, but whats the point... There is "maintenance" but its not realistic even on hard setting: you cant plow whole day without changing plow heads as they become dull and are eaten away by erosion. There are high quality more expensive "original" pieces and cheap black market knockoffs, but nothing like that in game. No storms or wildlife that destroys your crop.
Plow: lower it and drive like a car, no problem doing circles or turning 180... totally broken.
Manual gears/hp/torque: load your little tractor with massive trailer, put in the top gear, and just drive away like its nothing... i guess infinite torque/power or some kind of magical gear box...  try doing that on a real tractor lol. There should be "enable simulation" for the non arcade gamers.
 Then again average Joe would not like it and it would be "too complicated" and hence this is very basic "on the surface simulation" without much depth, more like to teach kids what is farm and where milk comes from. ( Source: retired farm boi)

Graphics:
Only tractors,attachments look OK( and you can scale them to 200% 3D resolution... why?!), looks like you put high poly tractor and throw it on low poly world, pretty much it. View range( lod,details,shadows) is barely ok when maxed out and playing exclusively from cabin first person view. There seems to be no ambient light at all in world? no occlusion so shadows look "cheap" and gives it 2000s feel(for a game in 2022...) The sky is either burning depths inferno or just weird not fitting overblown bright. I guess they tried to focus on beautiful sunset/sunrise with minimal effort, but ended up with creepy plastic surgery fail face equivalent. There seems to be no atmosphere either, no heat rising, you can see 999999999km without any deterioration of vision in 31C in hot summer day... No depth of field either. The map borders look so low poly that I think im playing Doom 95...
The rain is there, but you don't see it interacting with anything like the front glass or water... The sounds is quite good for thunder, but never seen lightning :(

World visuals was clearly not top or even middle of their prio list. I hope they ditch this engine and make new game in UE5 with better LOD,shadows,distance etc.


Economy:
Hoard and sell at high price or feed drip. Has some production chains, some pay a lot, some are totally not worth it like some oils production.
Borrow and repay $$ only with increments of 5k. want to borrow 200k? clickfest!
Many ways to cheeze money.

Multiplayer:
At least it works, with some weird rubber banding that is tied to fps??? if the host is experiencing fps drop for whatever reason ,you as client, will gain turbo nitro on your tractor and, well, hope you are going straight line and there is no water/ditch and you are not carrying full load... The listing of servers appears usually after few minutes of clicking back and forward "join multiplayer game" and "back to menu", because they couldn't figure out how to implement "refresh server list"

On the same topic: WTF IS UP WITH "SYNCING WITH OTHER PLAYERS" when someone joins a server and everything is frozen for 3 minutes lol. Never heard of async calls? Imagine WoW gets frozen everytime someone joins the server, or CoD or Destiny, or any other fricking online game gets frozen for new client to sync with other players LOL LOL LOL. This would never get trough code review if I was checking it...

Building:
"collides with another object" that is invisible so FU! go get place anywhere mod and be done with it, but it does not work with grapes...
Want to remove rocks/boulders from your field? Pay up and get DLC... And even then you can not remove all of them.

Grapes:
can only "extend" them downhill or on flat, so no making beautiful hill vineyard...

Logging:
eh logs are hard to pick up because the ground does not deform, aka you cant scoop them up. The claws are funny... they bend backwards and all kinds of rubbery madness. stay away from logging unless you enjoy trailers that are possessed and move on their own and logs flying/yeeting you in the air.

Bales stacking:
if you fancy picking the bales with tractor( and not autoloaders), you got to be very precise. The bales do not act like bales, but some rubbery bouncy objects.Way too much bounce. Booped the bale? whole stack is jiggling and vibrating and about to fly to space.

Harvesting:
Any attachment attaches to any combine: smallest engine and 15m header looks silly :D
same with tractor attachments. At some point tractor hp comes in to play. 

Precison farming DLC(free):
With this dlc some equipment becomes obsolete( even before this DLC), Some game-play loops become punishing(plowing, cultivating) so you got to opt out for least work and most combo machines. 

I would like to see more QoL, graphical improvements and balancing for it to be worth full price.

I have to say that this game is actually damn good if you just buy the base game and plan to use quite a few mods.  That said,  Giants has a habit of regurgitating content in a new color and calling it "new".  They have very rarely added any meaningful features to the game that modders didn't do the work for them already.  It's the same cycle of release, dlc's, platinum/premium editions, and more dlc's.  "New" machines(old machines reskinned as something else).  About 10 years of farming simulator and I have never seen an actual expansion from them.  They just don't seem genuine or to even value consumers' opinions.  People have been making the same complaints for years and it keeps going to this day.

So if you just buy the base game and play with mods you'll probably be surprised at how much fun it can be while also being very calming.  Just don't spend any money on the garbage upgrades and dlc's.  Modders do it better than Giants does themselves.

This is the first and only Farm Simulator I have played, but I have really enjoyed my time with it; ~70 hours and feel that I've only scratched the surface. I have played almost exclusively on the Steam Deck, and while it runs pretty well, there are extremely frustrating "micro stutters" quite often, so much so that I had to stop playing because they bugged me. I assumed this was due to weaker hardware, but it does the exact same thing on the gaming PC I just built (AMD 6700XT, 32GB RAM) and have seen enough people with the same issue online that it must be some lack of optimization within the game. My only other complaint is that the vehicle steering needs some more customizability to make it enjoyable on a gamepad. It's extremely jerky because the wheel just turns instantaneously in response to the joysticks - there needs to be some "weight" to it. The ability to set some speed and/or snapback limits would be great - SnowRunner does a good job of making the steering have some feel and weight to it that this game lacks and it makes the tractor driving and truck driving a lot less fun than it could be.

Title: A Deep Dive into Agricultural Realism - 4/5 Stars

Farming Simulator offers an immersive and surprisingly engaging experience for players looking to dive into the world of agriculture. With its attention to detail and commitment to realism, this game provides an authentic farming simulation that can captivate both veterans of the genre and newcomers alike. While not without its flaws, Farming Simulator manages to cultivate a rewarding gaming experience that keeps players coming back for more.

Gameplay: The core gameplay mechanics of Farming Simulator are its strongest selling points. The simulation is meticulously crafted, allowing players to engage in a wide array of farming activities from plowing and planting to harvesting and animal husbandry. The variety of crops, machinery, and equipment available is impressive, and the satisfaction of watching your virtual farm thrive is truly gratifying. The controls are intuitive, making it accessible to players of all skill levels. However, some actions may feel a bit monotonous after extended gameplay, which prevents a perfect score.

Realism and Immersion: Farming Simulator excels in delivering a remarkably realistic experience. The attention to detail in both the farming processes and the environments is commendable. The changing seasons, day-night cycle, and dynamic weather patterns not only affect the gameplay but also contribute to the immersive ambiance. The level of authenticity in how crops grow, animals behave, and machinery operates adds an educational aspect to the game that's both entertaining and informative.

Graphics and Sound: While the visuals in Farming Simulator are generally solid, they don't necessarily push the boundaries of modern gaming technology. The landscapes and machinery are well-designed and realistic, but some textures and character animations could benefit from further refinement. The sound design, particularly the ambient sounds of the farm and the hum of the machinery, enhance the immersion, but the overall soundtrack could use more variety.

Content and Progression: Farming Simulator offers a significant amount of content to explore, from various types of crops to a wide selection of machinery. The game encourages players to expand their farms, manage resources efficiently, and maximize profits. However, some players might find the progression a bit slow-paced, especially during the early stages of the game. More guidance or goal-setting options could help keep players engaged and motivated.

Community and Mods: One of Farming Simulator's strongest assets is its dedicated community of players and modders. The game's modding support allows players to customize and expand their experience significantly. From adding new crops and equipment to altering gameplay mechanics, the modding community breathes new life into the game regularly, enhancing its replayability and longevity.

Final Verdict:
Farming Simulator offers an immersive and engaging farming simulation experience that stands out due to its attention to realism and its supportive modding community. While the graphics and some gameplay aspects could use a bit more polish, the overall package delivers a rewarding and educational journey into the world of agriculture. Whether you're a seasoned virtual farmer or new to the genre, Farming Simulator offers a fruitful gaming experience worthy of a 4/5 star rating.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Farming Simulator 2022 is an absolute gem that provides an incredibly immersive and enjoyable farming experience. As a fan of simulation games, I was blown away by the level of detail, the wide range of activities, and the sheer joy that comes from tending to your virtual farm.

Pros:

Immersive Realism: The attention to detail in this game is truly remarkable. From plowing fields to milking cows, every aspect of farming feels authentic and engaging.
Expansive Open World: The world in Farming Simulator 2022 is vast and brimming with life. The various environments, landscapes, and weather conditions make each day on the farm feel unique and dynamic.
Diverse Activities: This game goes beyond just planting and harvesting crops. You can raise livestock, manage forestry operations, and even explore various machinery and vehicles – all of which adds depth to the gameplay.
Relaxing Gameplay: If you're looking for a game to unwind and escape the stresses of everyday life, Farming Simulator 2022 is perfect. The gentle pace and soothing ambiance are a breath of fresh air.
Modding Community: The active modding community enhances the game's replay value. Customization options are virtually limitless, allowing you to tailor your farming experience to your preferences.
Cons:

Learning Curve: For newcomers to the series or the genre, there might be a slight learning curve to understanding all the mechanics and systems. However, the in-game tutorials and guides do a good job of easing you in.
Progression Pace: Some players might find that progressing through certain aspects of the game takes time. While this adds to the realism, it could be a bit slow for those seeking faster-paced experiences.
Occasional Bugs: Like any game, there might be occasional bugs or glitches, but the developers seem dedicated to addressing these issues through updates.
In summary, Farming Simulator 2022 is an exceptional simulation game that manages to capture the essence of farming with stunning visuals, attention to detail, and a wealth of activities to immerse yourself in. Whether you're a seasoned fan of the series or new to farming simulations, this game offers hours of relaxing and rewarding gameplay. Get ready to roll up your sleeves, plant some seeds, and watch your virtual farm flourish – it's an experience that's both satisfying and therapeutic!

Finally reviewing one of my most played games, and there was a reason why I haven't reviewed it.. and that's because I was too busy playing it.

If you have played any previous Farming Simulator from this developer then you should really know what to expect and I suggest you read the "whats new" section of my review.


[b][u]Introduction[/u][/b]

This is a relaxing simulation about one of the hardest jobs in the world, and I am not saying that to win favour with the real farming community, it genuinely does seem difficult. We have mods and other controls that can enhance our experience, I am sure a real farmer would love the ability to pick up an entire pallet of seeds with their bare hands, or just rock up next to a big bag and press the "r" button to fill their equipment, but instead they have to do it properly, using forks to lift these things up, angle it over the hoppers and feed it in without spilling any...

So lets get that out the way, this is a game and should not be compared to real farming, however it does use real world tools and equipment (some are flights of fantasy if you delve into mods - more on that later). It tries to give you a geniune but fun experience.

This game is not without its challenges and this is what makes it appealing to me, there is no real "end goal" only what you set out, which I do recommend you do to give you some reason to play.. like for example have a certain amount of money in the bank? own all the map? run a self efficient farm with animals where you produce your own feed and productions? A mixture of all or whatever.

An example of my average gameplay is to start with minimum equipment, low funds, a small plot of land and have to start my own empire from nothing, either relying on expensive loans or working for other people.

This game does include various elements that can make the game more realistic or just easier whatever you fancy, for example are you going to worry about crop destruction? running over fields could ruin your harvest and take away any profits? Are you going to worry about plowing the fields, every now and then you may need to "reset" the soil before the next seeding or it will ruin the next yeild, weeds? Are you going to have to worry about these getting in the way of the crops? And the Precision Farming DLC which adds a whole new level of field management and I can't play without it.

Its a game you can jump into and then forget for a while and still remember why you love it. Sure its not for everyone but if you are here on this page you are either here because you are generally interested or just here to troll like its a new thing.

Fact is this game can be enjoyable even if you have little to no interest in farming, watch some youtubers completly wreck this game (GrayStillPlays done one on FS19 and I found it funny, he seemed to enjoy it) and that brings me onto the next topic... the Mods..


[b][u]Modding capabilities[/u][/b]

This game survives on Mods, there is an official ModHub in game that is home to literally thousands of mods of various equipment, maps and gameplay scripts. They could help or hinder your gameplay and without the mods this game can get pretty boring fast... That being said, I do recommend you play without mods first of all so you get to know the basics, then start introducing mods as you play.

Some mods I would recommend are:

Better Contracts
Contracts+
VIP Contracts
Easy Development Controls
Lumberjack
Shop Sales Customiser

These will help you in your gameplay and give you better rewards and other perks when completing contracts (or again hinder them) like you can make it that you can only start borrowing equipment when doing contracts when you have completed some jobs for that farmer, or you can earn a discount on field purchases the more jobs you do for them? The choice is all yours.

There are so many mods out there and I suggest you try them out rather than asking people what they would suggest.
There are new productions (again more on that later) modded productions, lots of different vehicles and tools, some are just for fun (The Flintstones car for example) and others are just mad (a small combine with a tank that is 5x too big for it)

And finally Maps... Its maps that you want in this game you start off with a few maps that are fine, however you may get bored with these soon enough, the fact that there are always maps being released for this game means there is always something for everyone, they range from small farms, to massive or even empty lands where you got to develop it from the ground up (try "No Mans Land") to massive forrestry maps where you have to clear out before you can start doing any other farming.

Precision Farming - official DLC, this can take your game to a whole new level, however its not for everyone and may take some time getting used to it, but once you do, you might not go back.


[b][u]So Whats New[/u][/b]

As I previously stated if you played any previous farming simulators then most of this review wont appeal to you, but you want to know what sets this apart. 

First of all it must be stated that a lot of these "new" features aren't exactly "new" they have been available in previous versions as Mods from the community, but we are discussing that they are now part of the base game and don't require any other mods (although you can download mods to change them up if needs be)

first of all is the inclusion of Seasons, this is the first time it has been "as standard" in a Farm Sim game and its been done pretty well, again if you have used Seasons in a previous game this won't be that new to you, but it is how it sounds, the weather will change throughout the year, and you have a crop calender which determines what can be planted and when it can be harvested.

Its basic but still enjoyable, and can make a challenge if you don't plan your crop rotations correctly, so youre not standing around doing nothing. Seasons can run as little to 1 day per month, to 30 days per month, I personally would only run around 3 days per month, unless you are running a massive farm with a lot to do, but you can change this and even turn it on and off whenever you want.


And then there are Production Chains, again something that was a mod in previous versions, but this is now as standard, before in the base game you send your product to a sell point make money, rince and repeat, now you can buy or setup your own productions, and make a final product, for example you take your grain to a mill, turn it into flour, take that flour to a bakery, with milk and butter, and strawberries from the greenhouses and it can make cakes. Its no lie.

[b][u]Final Verdict[/u][/b]

Its not for everyone sure but then what game is? But it is more enjoyable and addictive than you might think, if you get hooked you will get hooked. It has a great community, that are constantly modding and supporting this game, and there are some multiplayer benefits (I haven't tried the multiplayer aspects but I am sure they are fun). I would wait for the Premium edition to be released before buying it (at time of writing this August 2023). And it is available on GamePass..

Also the stuttering you get at the start, is normal, just power through it, things will get better I promise, don't mess with settings just power through it, you can do it.

I played previous Farming Simulator games and really enjoyed them, this game is just so lazy I feel like an investment fund just bought the rights to the title. The bugs I came across just made me frustrated and every one can be googled because someone else had them. I did a mission to harvest a field, the mission log said 85% complete despite a fully harvested field, people with the same issue worked out you need to chop down a tree next to the field and it might be fixed, chopping down a tree means buying  the equipment to chop down a tree and a significant amount of grinding to afford it, not to mention you literally need to chop down the damn tree, or many trees if you don't figure out which tree is causing the issue. I had a mission to fertilze a field, 3 times I had a message that the worker could not find the field at various points of completion, the only way I can explain it is that you need to navigate the glitched parts of the field and the worker will find it again. The third time i managed to get the worker to find the field he fertilized a river and two roads before again losing the field at which point i requested a refund. Play Farming simulator 2019, at least it works and it's much cheaper.

My name is LadyBoys and Im 31 years old I believe in taking care of myself, and a balanced diet and a rigorous exercise routine. In the morning, if my face is a little puffy, I’ll put on an ice pack while doing my stomach crunches. I can do a thousand now. After I remove the ice pack I use a deep pore cleanser lotion. In the shower I use a water activated gel cleanser, then a honey almond body scrub, and on the face an exfoliating gel scrub. Then I apply an herb-mint facial masque which I leave on for 10 minutes while I prepare the rest of my routine. I always use an after shave lotion with little or no alcohol, because alcohol dries your face out and makes you look older. Then moisturizer, then an anti-aging eye balm followed by a final moisturizing protective lotion. There is an idea of a Ladyboys. Some kind of abstraction. But there is no real me. Only an entity. Something illusory. And though I can hide my cold gaze, and you can shake my hand and feel flesh gripping yours, and maybe you can even sense our lifestyles are probably comparable, I simply am not there.

I have been a long time supporter of Giants and the farming simulator franchise, having all previous released titles on pc since 08 edition and most of the DLC throughout the years, not to mention getting others to buy and play the games.  And while I was annoyed by how fs19 dlc was handled, when those of us that supported the developer and purchased the game and some DLC along the way as they were released got no bundle rebate on steam (for parts of bundle we already own), nothing come close to how Giants are treating your customers with the Platinum Edition crap they are pulling this time around. 

A new player getting into the game now can get the FS22 Premium edition, getting the base game and both season passes including platinum expansion for 40 Euro.  This is a good deal, I'm not complaining about this, it's a fair price for this late in the game lifecycle. 

But if I, with the base game, try to purchase Premium Edition on steam I get the following message: 
[i]Farming Simulator 22: Premium Edition
You already own some of the items in this bundle. This offer is only available when buying all items at the same time.[/i]

So, according to Steam and how [b]Giants [/b]spesifically asked them to set the pricing.. 
Me wanting to get the full experience of FS22, having already paid 40 euro for the base when it came out, now have to pay 40 euro for year 1 season pass and 40 euro for year 2 pass. An additional 80 euro, a total of 120, instead of 40, just because I dared to buy the base game when it came out.

I get and agree on giving a bundle price for new players late to the game, giving a good value bundle price to entice them to the franchise. 
But you can do so without shitting over your existing players and tell them to go buy everything at full price just because they had the gall to purchase the game when it came out and wait for dlc to release. 

You price it as if you only have 2 types of customers, those that buy base game + season passes right as they come out (this is fine, they get content as it rolls out, ignoring the dlc outside of season pass issue), and those that buy into the game at the end of the game development, and only wants to because a heavy discount. 

Sure I could try and buy Premium Edition as a gift and claim it for myself, again getting no value for my existing purchase of the base game.
But having to circumvent steam store just to get the bundle price is ridiculous, not to mention most people don't know how steam handles gifted bundles when you own an item in that bundle already, just having to gamble that it works. 

At a minimum give me the option to buy the same editions as new players have, direct in Steam, there is no reason at all to lock that option from existing players.  

But preferably let existing owned items be deducted from the bundle base cost, with the same bundle discount applied for remaining items. 
Like [b]EVERY [/b]other developer is doing! 

Get your act together Giants!


I get that I'm most likely screaming into the void, but I for one is never going to buy a new FS game until the "final" premium bundle is out unless this changes, if at all.  And I will be directly recommending noone anyone else do either, both in friends circles and elsewhere.

Having come from the FS17 and FS19 games on console and now having a PC. Its a game changer with the modding. although its a pain to have to pay for the good mods, at least you still have the game stuff. And i don't even know where to start with the precision farming DLC. the amount of detail that this game sets you into with the PH levels, the nitrogen and last but not least yield expectation!?. not only that put putting your grain in bins to have them sit until the sell points are at a high for buying. its incredible. There is many things that still need to be corrected. this game needs more interaction. like an animation to get into vehicles. In video games its always the small things that matter. I also think that the landscaping system needs an entire revamp. i understand that in 2019 the landscaping aspect was new and awaited to be perfected. Its so hard to sculpt land. i also thing that the leveling process for placing down sheds needs a good revamp as well. i don't like that the land becomes a hard square part of ground that comes up. I think it should be fixed into a piece of concrete that adjusts to what it needs to be leveled at. But in all honesty this game is top tier and i cant wait for the upcoming ones and its worth the $40

Farming Simulator is therapeutic exercise for your brain. Its gameplay systems are deep enough to enable meaningful expression of a player's agronomic will without punishing you harshly for mistakes or bad luck. It encourages you to experiment and find your own best practices. If a scheme doesn't work out, you can always sell off and try something else. Some people grow grain. Some grow vegetables. Still others raise livestock. How exactly to spend your daylight is an ongoing journey.

I highly recommend the new seasonal growth option. Inspired by the Season mod from the previous game, it adds a time dimension that provides structure to gameplay. Repetitive chores becomes yearly rituals. Off seasons become time for experimentation and speculation. Crop scheduling becomes a puzzle with many solutions.

If you're looking for cutthroat business sim, you'll be disappointed. Farming Simulator 22 is a game for chilling out and letting your mind wander.

As an avid fan of the Farming Simulator series, I couldn't wait to dive into the latest installment from Giants Software. With each release, my expectations for a more realistic and immersive farming experience grew, but sadly, I find myself somewhat disappointed with the recent developments.

Undoubtedly, the game has its merits, but it's hard not to notice the missed potential for true authenticity. One aspect that stood out to me was the ground and weight physics on the machines. With Giants Software's substantial budget, I had hoped for a leap forward in this area. Realistic weight distribution and terrain deformation would have added an unparalleled level of depth and realism to the gameplay, making the farming activities truly come alive.

One of the features that I was particularly excited about was the first-person view inside the tractor. I imagined being able to reach out and interact with buttons and levers just like a real farmer would, adding an extra layer of immersion. However, to my disappointment, this level of detail was absent, leaving the tractor experience feeling somewhat detached from reality.

Farming Simulator revolves around spending countless hours driving tractors, and I expected a more polished approach to animations in this context. A well-crafted animation while driving could have breathed life into the in-game character and made the whole experience more engaging and personal.

On the subject of downloadable content (DLC), I must admit that while I appreciate the effort put into creating new content, the recent offerings have been less than satisfying. Some of the DLCs feel lackluster and come with a rather hefty price tag, which leaves me questioning their value.

I don't mean to overlook the positives, but I can't help but feel that Giants Software could have put their ample resources to better use. Instead of investing in expensive yet unsatisfactory DLCs, I had hoped they would focus on enhancing the core gameplay with more realistic mechanics and features.

In conclusion, Farming Simulator has its strengths, and I admire the passion of the developers. However, the missed opportunities for true authenticity and immersion leave me longing for more. With a game that thrives on delivering a genuine farming experience, it's crucial for Giants Software to listen to the community's feedback and prioritize the elements that truly matter. As a dedicated fan, I look forward to future updates that address these concerns and elevate the farming simulation to new heights. Until then, it feels like a promising experience that hasn't quite blossomed to its full potential.

Another Edit: Was trying to stay away from the game but had a nagging curiosity on how the forestry side went.  Looks like Giants yet again didn't fix any of the forestry bugs from FS19.  Logs still pop right out through the logging tools.  Logs sometimes start to shift all on their own inside the trailer.  Logging tools get stuck on the trees they are cutting down.

I seriously think the only thing Giants did with FS22 was update the graphics and added seasons which is worse than the modded seasons from FS19.  Modders seriously know how to code 1000x better than a Giants dev.

Edit:  1.5 months later and game is still mostly bugged and I have learned that GIANT doesn't know how to do multicore coding which is why the game only utilizes 30% gpu loads and 50% of my gpu memory and only 15% of my cpu usage.  Surprisingly the game only uses about 2-3 GB of ram and yet it at times runs like a pig.  You can even set the graphics low and it doesn't help because there is probably some really bad coding.

The patch before Christmas did next to nothing for the game.  Yes many of them are just quality of life issues but some are annoying. But at least they fixed the contracts that required 100,000 liters from a 0.5ha field haha.  But they haven't fixed it so the AI farms do there own work and all there crops just sit there withered and full of weeds unless you go and do the work for them so it looks really stupid driving down the roads.  And those two examples are just the start of it.

After the patch I found 3 of my crops withered, key binds were all gone, and two of my structures disappeared and they were not even mod structures.

Then there is damage rates of vehicles.  You don't want to repair vehicles because it costs about 10x more than you make from selling crops at peak selling times.  So you have to keep your vehicles and equipment broken to operate.

The amount of stones they show on fields looks really stupid.  A field after plowing looks more like a quarry than a field with mix of some large rocks  here and there.  These guys really need to go do some volunteer work on farms to see what really happens.  Or at least watch some youtube videos of farmers who have plowed a grass field under.  There are rocks pulled up but no where near what it looks like in game.

If this is the quality of work people from GIANT do, I wouldn't want to hire them should they go looking for jobs when there done at GIANT.


Really disappointed with Giant software and the way they develop.  FS22 has very few original ideas added to it.  Most of the update is graphics (which I don't like) or adding stuff modders already added to the game.  So basically profiting off other peoples ideas (seasons, production chains).  Not that I don't want to see that being added, but it seems so little and not done as well other than graphics maybe.

For example:  FS19 modded Seasons gives more weather info, such as chance of precipitation and crop rotations.

As for graphics, things seem more blurry.  It is like the farmer always has bad eye sight.  Tried turning on MSAA but it has bad stutters, not sure they coded it correctly.  I've used MSAA in huge amounts of other games with barely any FPS loss.

They did not improve the AI, they made it worse.  Luckily the AI doesn't damage fields.  But I've watched the AI drive a harvester back into the field it needs to cut.  The AI vehicles still don't stop at stop signs so expect to get rammed if you don't yield to traffic at all intersections.

I was also hoping since they seem to be supporting north american map better that they'd add more american equipment.  But still 99% of the equipment has the EU hazard stripes rather than triangles.  Not sure why they even bothered to put in a US based map.  Thus they really lack in game immersion.

Only thing I really liked over a modded FS19 is that they added gear shifting and a bit of force feedback which in itself was a shoddy type of FFB.  Basically just added some centering spring force.  As for gear shifting, it would have been better if they had control settings grouped into vehicle types.  So CVT drive vehicles use certain gamepad/wheel bindings.  And things like the Manual + Powershift would have there own, so that no bindings overlap.  Same goes for trucks which they could have setup similar to how ATS/ETS2 have setup.

Overall, I personally feel a person is better off playing FS19 modded until people have remade there mods for FS22.  And from reading forums, it could take a couple of months to get enough mods that will make FS22 worth it.  So basically if you use a lot of mods, stick to FS19 for a bit longer.  My main point is, if your going to add what modders made to the vanilla version of the game, do it 100% or preferably 120-150% better because the modders are sometimes limited by the main game itself.

First things first, the graphics in this game are so crisp, it's like someone polished every corn stalk individually. Seriously, the fields are lush and vibrant, and the farm machinery looks so shiny you'd think it just rolled off a showroom floor. I half expected my tractor to start blasting tunes and ask if I wanted fries with that!

And speaking of machinery, Farming Simulator 2022 has more options than a buffet on cheat day. We've got tractors of all shapes and sizes, harvesters that are like giant metal Pac-Men gobbling up crops, and even tools that make gardening look like a dance party. Who knew farming could be this cool?

Now, let's talk game-play. Planting and harvesting crops have never been so addictive! It's like playing a high-stakes version of Whack-A-Mole, but instead of moles, you're smacking seeds into the ground and harvesting them like a champ. The controls are smooth as butter, and even if you have butter fingers, you'll still feel like a pro farmer.

What really cracked me up were the new crop varieties they've thrown into the mix. I mean, who needs just corn and wheat when you can grow wild stuff like purple potatoes or rainbow carrots? Farming Simulator 2022 is like a fashion show for fruits and veggies. I wouldn't be surprised if there's a hidden unicorn crop waiting to be discovered!

Now, I have to admit, this game isn't all sunshine and rainbows. The AI could use a little extra brainpower, especially when it comes to our lovely NPCs. They sometimes wander around like lost sheep or stare at you with a vacant expression that says, "I have no idea what I'm doing." But hey, we all have those days, right?

Overall, Farming Simulator 2022 is a hilarious, comedic farming extravaganza that's perfect for anyone who wants a break from reality and dive headfirst into a virtual farm. It's the kind of game that'll have you laughing at the absurdity of it all while secretly getting emotionally attached to your pixelated crops.

So grab a straw hat, put on your best farming playlist, and get ready to plow, plant, and laugh your way through Farming Simulator 2022. It's a farming adventure that's as fun as watching pigs dance and cows do the Mac-arena. Yeehaw!

Farming Simulator 22 is an incredibly realistic and immersive farming simulator that offers a truly authentic farming experience. The game's focus on realism and attention to detail make it a truly engaging and enjoyable experience for players of all ages. The game's vast open-world maps and variety of crops and animals to manage also add to the overall immersion, making it feel like you're really running your own farm. 

One of the standout features of Farming Simulator 22 is the game's incredibly realistic graphics and sound design. The game's visuals are truly stunning, with highly detailed environments and realistic lighting effects that bring the world to life. The game's sound design is also top-notch, with realistic sound effects for everything from the tractors, machinery, implements and equipment to the animals and ambient nature sounds.

Another key feature of Farming Simulator 22 is the game's deep and engaging gameplay. Players must manage every aspect of their farm, from planting and harvesting crops to caring for livestock and managing finances. The game's realistic physics and weather systems also add to the overall immersion, making it feel like you're really working on a farm.

Overall, Farming Simulator 22 is a must-play for anyone who loves simulation games and is looking for a truly immersive and engaging experience. The game's vast open-world map, realistic graphics and sound design, and deep gameplay make it a standout title in the genre. Additionally, the game's active and passionate modding community provides endless possibilities for customization and new content, ensuring that the game will remain fresh and engaging for years to come.

Oh geeze, where to start...
Been playing FS since 2017.  Nice incremental improvements in 2019 and then in 2022, but I'm underwhelmed, especially considering that FS2022 has been full price (and more than previous releases) for almost a year before the first sale.  When I say "full price", I mean close to AAA games.  FS is NOT a AAA title, and worse, there's still plenty of add-on content to purchase to get everything, such as "Platinum Edition" which doesn't include Year 1 Season, Year 2 Season, etc... ok, anyways, let's get behind pricing and value (bang for your buck).

CaseIH has been mostly nerfed in FS2022.  It's probably not the only brand but the most noticeable for me coming from FS'19.  I get that John Deere is the new hot commodity -- and I suspect that the licensing deal is part of the explanation for increased pricing -- but come on, did we really have to make it THIS obvious?  Several CaseIH models are missing and some that are in the game are almost a joke.  It's almost like each release of Farm Sim is now going to be themed around a specific brand.  Is that really the way to go?  Lol, no, because it's just not right.

Ok, so some are thinking I'm a brand loyalist at this point.  Let me REALLY get into the nitty-gritty now.
 
!!! PROS !!!
*Runs well on Ryzen 7000-series (almost no CPU utilization) and Radeon RX 7900 XT (about 50% utilization at 1440p @ 60 Hz, max settings).  DX12 introduction new for FS22 is NICE -- almost introduces a problem where it's TOO GPU bound and not enough CPU bound, lol.  Not complaining here though -- TY devs.  Not sure where Vulkan stands though...
*Crop seasons, raw variety of different equipment to purchase, and great native mod support are definitely wins.
* Multiplayer is nice... even if it has a lot of room for improvement (I elaborate on this later)
* Physics seems to have improved, though it's still not like that found in SnowRunner and some other sims/excellent off-road physics games
**ADDED 25JUN2023:  I'm generally enjoying the game enough to continue logging hours on it, so it's not all doom and gloom, lol.  I did have to recover an auto-saved game after my son sold a bunch of my equipment for some other "fun stuff" that wasn't really practical... anyways, my point is that I appreciate that relatively robust save-game system.  The wife has been playing Sims 4 for like 10 years and still no auto-save, LMAO.

!!! CONS !!!
* CaseIH and other brands being nerfed or less models available in favor of John Deere
* Only four maps?  Really!?
* Rolling can't be turned off.  Not a common thing in the U.S. Midwest so kind of odd...
* Limited number of online radio stations; why can't this be more easily customized??
* Bushes are hard to get rid of -- painting ground textures (grass, gravel, etc.) is the only guaranteed bet but costs money
* Landscaping is EXPENSIVE, **EDIT 25JUN2023** IDEA: Should be able to simulate changes and then choose to commit or discard
* The economy on medium difficulty is a bit expensive for equipment repairs (degrades condition too fast) and crops pay a bit low even with near 100% yield bonus which takes a lot of time to achieve such yields  **EDIT 25JUN2023** I also realize that passive income like animals, solar, etc. is a smart way to boost earnings, but either grain sales pays a little too low or maintenance costs/deteriation speed is too aggressive
* Contracted jobs pay low, especially when using one's own equipment (after factoring fuel and repairs) and for certain jobs types
* Contracted jobs seem to get stuck... e.g. baling and others that *EDIT* take a long time to  move on unless you complete them or at least start them and purposely fail them
* Having AI operate one's equipment is too expensive unless the very largest tractors, harvesters, implements, etc. is used, and even then profit margin is still questionable
* Variety of side-by-sides and farm trucks is laughable... modded trucks provide a way better value and more worthwhile, even for users trying to be "ultra-realistic".  
* Multiplayer should have an option for "realistic" vs. "arcade" whereas realistic means players don't ignore equipment boxes (falling inside and thru tractors, etc.) while arcade is the current style "players of equipment they aren't driving around bound to there dimensions and therefore "fall right through"
* Multiplayer should have a manual or automatic refresh option; my friend will create a game, but if I join too early, it doesn't show and won't ever show until I back all the way back out and go into 'Multiplayer' -> 'Join Game' again
* Similar to equipment condition, paint condition degrades WAAAYYYY too quickly, even for equipment that is stored under a shed or whatever with a roof and is properly maintained
*  There should be some kind of system for discounts, specials, etc. on seed, fertilizer, and other typically-palletized/bagged products.
* Still no tractor cab doors and windows that can't be opened unless its modded?  SAD times.
* Almost all manual and powershift transmissions are gone in tractors... B.S.!  This relates back to the fact that some brands don't have models from 10, 20, 30 years ago.  How about we have a "used market" for older equipment models; not every farmer wishes to purchase a brand-new, 0 hours tractor.
* Maps need to get bigger; semi trucks and other fast vehicles can get from one side to another in no time.  Maybe variable map sizes need to at least become an option the future, with higher-end systems able to play on those larger map sizes (talking stock, not just modded)
* No ability to control left/right brake pedals, diff locks, and 2WD vs. 4WD on capable tractors
* Tractors with CVT trannies still seem to rev high even when engine load is very low *EDIT 25JUN2023:  Not enough PowerShift or other manual/semi-manual trannies.  I think this also reflects that there should be more older-model tractors in the game as many farmers turn to the used market; buying 15-30 year old tractors in the U.S. is a very common practice
* Houses, sheds, etc. don't overcome chopped down trees, resulting in some weird foundations and auto-landscaping effects.  Their placement should either require complete elimation of trees and stumps or just raise the price of installation and automatically include the removal (my preference but maybe this could be a setting?)
* Loans should have more detail to them, e.g. lines of credit (similar to how it's down now on a monthly basis in small $5K increments) with more formal loans in larger allotments offering more specific pay-off and interest terms
* Ability to buy other farm houses, sheds, etc. on property that is purchased
* The high pressure washer isn't mobile and costs $5K?  Really?
EDIT (ADD):  * NPC traffic likes to turn right in front of you, causing a crash, even when one's own speed is constant, i.e. they should be able to calculate and predict if they should wait to turn or go ahead and make the turn.  They are aggressive drivers as it currently stands.
EDIT (ADD):  * When you purchase a dog, he/she runs in slow motion.  It literally had me and my son laughing out loud.  Otherwise, it's a nice touch and fun to play ball with him/her.
** EDIT (ADD) on 25JUN2023:  would really like to frame rate limiting natively built-in.

This may start to sound like a rant but when you charge near-AAA pricing for a game, one expects near-AAA features and such.  Furthermore, detailed feedback is how I believe the most important, juicy changes will come about, not high-level crabbing and moaning.  All these cons take away my enjoyment from this game, adding up in such a way that either has me not wanting to play anymore or at times thinking "man, FS'25 is going to be a real money-grab, huh?  Guess I won't touch FS anymore."  Nothing against the gaming business model of having DLC to add content and increase margin but a game like the FS franchise can't charge BOTH a high entry cost for the base game and tons in add-ons/DLC's and such.

Mechanics: 4.5/10

DLC: 0/10 (why do we need a season pass for a Farming Simulator)

Huge improvement from Farm Sim 17 and a decent improvement from Farm Sim 19! 
I only own Farm Sim 17, not 19. But I have done my research on 19. I am basing this review on the difference from 17 to 22.

The Good:
- More stuff to do. More crops, more vehicles, more contracts and more animals to own (Bees, Horses, Sheep). 
- Better graphics, sounds (everything now has a sound to it) and maps. The graphics can look crude in some places though.
- Some level of wildlife is actually in the game now. You will see deer and crows.
- You can now own dogs but they can't herd for you. It would be cool if they added this though.
- Seasons and companies now incorporated into base game. You can own companies now. 
- You now have to buy land, not just fields.
- New hard mode. You can now start from nothing.

The bad:
- Physics could still use some work. 
- Vehicles still feel arcadey. 
- Collision detection and gravity is still awkward. You will get stuck walking on foot and you can glue yourself to walls.
- Giant needs to listen to the fans more. Any popular mod that everyone uses needs to be implemented into the game.
- Too much DLC. They are spacing the next release further and further away (its now 2023 and still no new mainline release) so I understand they need to make money. But we are now approaching the sims level of DLC. This does discourage some people from buying the game. 

DLC is 100% not needed though! Base game is enough. You can download mods to tailor the game to your liking.

Overall, I'm happy but I do understand if you own 19 you may be hesitant to buy 22. It's £25 for the base game and I'll probably play this for at least a hundred hours so its worth the money to me. 

If you're new to the franchise, don't buy this expecting AAA level of quality. Its a AA game. If you don't own any Farm Sim game, then buy this one. This is the best version.

The game itself is great, or I wouldn't have played it for 500 hours (except for the forestry, where the textures doesn't match the model/hitbox unless the tree is super-straight), but the multiplayer is terrible. It starts with the fact that you still can't connect with friends via Steam and have to hope that a friend's server will be suggested to you. Sometimes you have to restart the game 5-6 times for that to happen, but sometimes you see the server as soon as it starts. Once you've found the server, you have to spend 20-30 seconds syncing the game data, pausing the game for everyone, then repeating the previous process, because sometimes terraformed objects or textures are set to default locally, which is then fixed by reconnecting. Then when you are finally in the game, desync or rubberbanding occurs. I don't know of any other game where this is so extreme. 
The multiplayer is the only thing besides mods that keeps the game alive, so it's even sadder that it's so poorly implemented. I really hope these issues are fixed in the next installment and am disappointed that even Farming Simulator 2011 runs more stable.
